Bibliographic details for the Source Text Thomas Dekker, ca. 1572-1632 (1572?-1632) Satiro-mastix. Or The vntrussing of the Humorous Poet. As it hath bin presented publikely, by the Right Honorable, the Lord Chamberlaine his Seruants; and priuately, by the Children of Paules. By Thomas Dekker London Printed for Edward VVhite [etc.] 1602 [90] p. Preliminaries and introductory matter omitted.
Play details
Satiro-mastix. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1602. Date first performed: 1601.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
1 Gentlewoman 2 Gentlewoman Sir Quintilian Shorthose Peter Flash Sir Walter Terill Crispinus Sir Rees ap Vaughan Sir Adam Prickshaft Mistress Miniver Asinius Bubo Tucca King Cælestine Horace Demetrius Fannius Blunt 1 Lady Dicach Boy Servant Prologue and Epilogue Philocalia Lady Petula combined voice

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.p:
Satiro-mastix. OR The vntrussing of the Humorous Poet.
Front matter
Non recito cuiquam nisi Amicis idque coactus.
Dramatis personæ.
1 1. William Rufus. 2. Sir Walter Terill. 3. Sir Rees ap Vaughan. 4. S. Quintilian Shorthose. 5. Sir Adam Prickshaft. 6. Blunt. 7. Crispinus. 8. Demetrius Fannius. 9. Tucca. 10. Horace. 11. Asinius Bubo. 12. Peter Flash. 13. Cælestine. 14. Mistress Miniuer. 15. Ladies.
To the VVorld.

div2.stage: Enter two Gentlewomen strewing of flowers.

sp.l: Come bedfellow come, strew apace, strew, strew: in good troth it is pity that these flowers must be trodden under feet as they are like to be anon.

Pity, alack pretty heart, thou art sorry to see any good thing fall to the ground: pity? no more pity, than to see an Innocent Maidenhead delivered up to the ruffling of her new-wedded husband. Beauty is made for use, and he that will not use a sweet soul well, when she is under his fingers, I pray Venus he may never kiss a fair and a delicate, soft, red, plump-lip.
Amen, and that is torment enough.

Pity? come fool fling them about lustily; flowers never die a sweeter death, than when they are smothered to death in a Lovers bosom, or else pave the high ways, over which these pretty, simpering, jetting things, called brides, must trip.
I pray thee tell me, why do they use at weddings to furnish all places thus, with sweet herbs and flowers?
One reason is, because it is --- o a most sweet thing to lie with a man.
I think it is a O more more more more sweet to lie with a woman.

I warrant all men are of thy mind: another reason is, because they stick like the scutcheons of madam chastity,
on the sable ground, weeping in their stalks, and winking with their yellow-sunk eyes, as loath to behold the lamentable fall of a Maidenhead: what senseless thing in all the house, that is not now as melancholy, as a new set-up Schoolmaster?
Troth I am.

Troth I think thou mournest, because thou hast missed thy turn, I do by the quiver of Cupid: you see the torches melt themselves away in tears: the instruments wear their heart strings out for sorrow: and the Silver Ewers weep most pitiful Rosewater: five or six pair of the white innocent wedding gloves, did in my sight choose rather to be torn in pieces than to be drawn on; and look this Rosemary, (a fatal herb) this deadman's nose-gay, has crept in amongst these flowers to deck in the invisible coarse of the Brides Maidenhead, when (O how much do we poor wenches suffer) about eleven or twelve, or one a clock at midnight at furthest, it descends to purgatory, to give notice that Cælestine (hey ho) will never come to lead Apes in hell.
I see by thy sighing thou wilt not.
If I had as many Maiden-heads, as I have hairs on my head, I would venture them all rather than to come into so hot a place; prithee strew thou, for my little arms are weary.
I am sure thy little tongue is not.

No faith that is like a woman bitten with fleas, it never lies
still: fie upon it, what a miserable thing it is to be a noble Bride, there is such delays in rising, in fitting gowns, in tiring, in pinning Rebatoes, in poking, in dinner, in supper, in Revels, and last of all in cursing the poor nodding fiddlers, for keeping Mistress Bride so long up from sweeter Revels; that, O I could never endure to put it up without much bickering.
Come thou art an odd wench, hark, hark, music? nay then the Bride is up.

Is she up? nay then I see she has been down: Lord have mercy on us, we women fall and fall still, and when we have husbands we play upon them like Virginal Iackes, they must rise and fall to our humours, or else they will never get any good strains of music out of us; but come now, have at it for a maidenhead.

div2.stage:
strew.
As they strew, enter Sir Quintilian Shorthose with Peeter Flash and two or three seruingmen with lights.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Come knaves, night begins to be like myself, an old man; day plays the thief and steals upon us; O well done wenches, well done, well done, you have covered all the stony way to church with flowers, it is well, it is well, there is an Emblem too, to be made out of these flowers and stones, but you are honest wenches, in, in, in.
When we come to your years, we shall learn what honesty is, come pew-fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Is the music come yet? so much to do! Is it come?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Have the merry knaves pulled their fiddle cases over their instruments ears?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: As soon as ever they entered our gates, the noise went, before they came near the great Hall, the faint hearted villiacoes sounded at least thrice.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Thou shouldst have revived them with a Cup of burnt wine and sugar; sirrah, you, horse-keeper, go, bid them curry their strings: Is my daughter up yet?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: Up sir? she was seen up an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: She is an early stirrer, ah sirrah.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: She will be a late stirrer soon at night sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: Go too Peeter Flash, you have a good sudden flash of brain, your wits husky, and no marvel, for it is like one of our Comedians beards, still in the stubble: about your business and look you be nimble to fly from the wine, or the nimble wine will catch you by the nose.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: If your wine play with my nose Sir, I will knock his coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Do Peeter, and wear it for thy labour; Is my Son-in-Law Sir Walter Terell ready yet?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ready sir.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: One of you attend him: Stay Flash, where is the note of the guests you have invited?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l:
Here Sir, I will pull all your guests out of my bosom; the men that will come, I have crossed, but all the Gentlewomen
have at the tail of the last letter a prick, because you may read them the better.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: My spectacles, light, light, knaves: Sir Adam Prickshaft, thou hast crossed him, he will come.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: I had much ado sir, to draw Sir Adam Prickeshaft home, because I told him it was early, but he will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: Justice Crop, what will he come?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: He took physic yesterday sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: O: then Crop cannot come.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: O Lord yes, sir yes, it was but to make more room in his Crop for your good cheer, Crop will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: Widow Mineuer.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: She is pricked you see sir, and will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: Sir Uaughan ap Rees, O he is crossed twice, so, so, so, then all these Ladies, that fall downwards here, will come I see, and all these Gentlemen that stand right before them.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: All will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: Well said, here, write them out again, and put the men from the women; and Peeter, when we are at Church bring wine and cakes, be light and nimble good Flash, for your burden will be but light.

div2.stage: Enter sir Adam a light before him.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam Prickeshaft
sp.l: God morrow, god morrow go, in, in, in, to the Bridegroom, taste a cup of burnt wine this morning, it will make you fly the better all the day after.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.l: You are an early stirrer Sir Quintilian Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Sir qui
sp.l: I am so, it behooves me at my daughters wedding, in in, in; fellow put out thy torch, and put thyself into my buttery, the torch burns ill in thy hand, the wine will burn better in thy belly, in in.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: Ware there, room for Sir Adam Prickeshaft: your Worship ---

div2.stage: Enter Sir Vaughan and Mistris Mineuer .

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Sir Vaughan and Widow Mineuer, welcome, welcome, a thousand times: my lips Mistress Widow shall bid you God morrow, in, in, one to the Bridegroom, the other to the Bride.

sp.speaker: Vaughen.
sp.l: Why then Sir quiontilian Shorthose, I will step into mistress Bride, and Widow Mineuer, shall go upon M. Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Mineu.
sp.l: No pardon, for by my truly Sir Uaughan, I will have no dealings with any M. Bridegrooms.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: In widow in, in honest knight in.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaug.
sp.l: I will usher you mistress widow.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: Light there for sir Vaughan; your good Worship ---

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.l: Drink that shilling Ma. Peeter Flash, in your guts and belly.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I will not drink it down sir, but I will turn it into that which shall run down, O merrily!

div2.stage: Enter Blunt, Crispinus, Demetrius, and others with Ladies, lights before them.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l:
God morrow to these beauties, and Gentlemen, that have Ushered this troop of Ladies to my daughters
wedding, welcome, welcome all; musick? nay then the bridegroom is coming, where are these knaves here?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: All here sir.

div2.stage: Enter Terill, Sir Adam, Sir Vaughan, Celestine Mineuer , other Ladies and attendants with lights.

sp.speaker: Teri.
Cris.
sp.l: God morrow M. Bridegroom, mistress Bride.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: God morrow M. Bride groom.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Gallants I shall entreat you to prepare, For Masks and Revels to defeat the night, Our Sovereign will in person grace our marriage.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: What will the king be here?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Father he will.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Where be these knaves? More Rosemary and gloves, gloves, gloves: choose Gentlemen; Ladies put on soft skins upon the skin of softer hands; so, so: come mistress Bride take you your place, he old men first, and then the Bachelors; Maids with the Bride, Widows and wives together, the priest is at Church, it is time that we march thither

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Dear Blunt at our return from Church, take pains to step to Horace, for our nuptial songs; now Father when you please.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Agreed, set on, come good Sir Vaughan, must we lead the way?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Peeter you go too fast for Mistress pride: so, gingerly, gingerly; I muse why Sir Adam Prickeshaft sticks so short behind?

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: He follows close, not too fast, hold up knaves, Thus we lead youth to church, they us to graves.

div2.stage: Horrace sitting in a study behinde a Curtaine, a candle by him burning, bookes lying confusedly: to himselfe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To thee whose fore-head swells with Roses, Whose most haunted bower Gives life and sent to every flower, Whose most adored name encloses, Things abstruse, deep and divine, Whose yellow tresses shine, Bright as Eoan fire. O me thy Priest inspire. For I to thee and thine immortal name, In-in-in golden tunes, For I to thee and thine immortal name --- In - sacred raptures flowing, flowing, swimming, swimming: In sacred raptures swimming, Immortal name, game, dame, tame, lame, lame, lame, Pux, hath, shame, proclaim, O --- In Sacred raptures flowing, will proclaim, not --- O me thy Priest inspire! For I to thee and thine immortal name, In flowing numbers filled with sprite and flame, Good, good, in flowing numbers filled with sprite and flame.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Horace, Horace, my sweet ningle, is always in labour when I come, the nine Muses be his midwives I pray Iupiter: Ningle.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: In flowing numbers filled with sprite and flame, To thee.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: To me? I pledge thee sweet Ningle, by Bacchus quaffing bowl, I thought thou hadst drunk to me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It must have been in the divine liquor of Pernassus, then in which, I know you would scarce have pledged me, but come sweet rogue, sit, sit, sit.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Over head and ears i'faith? I have a sackful of news for thee, thou shalt plague some of them, if God send us life and health together.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It is no matter, empty thy sack anon, but come here first honest rogue, come.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Is it good, Is it good pure Helicon ha?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Damn me if it be not the best that ever came from me, if I have any judgment look sir, it is an Epithalamium for Sir Walter Terrels wedding, my brains have given assault to it but this morning.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Then I hope to see them fly out like gun-powder ere night.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nay good rogue mark, for they are the best lines that ever I drew.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l:
Here is the best leaf in England, but on, on, I will but
tune this Pipe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mark, to thee whose fore-head swells with Roses.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: O sweet, but will there be no exceptions taken, because fore-head and swelling comes together?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Push, away, away, its proper, besides it is an elegancy to say the fore head swells.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Nay if it be proper, let it stand for Gods love.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Whose most haunted bower, Gives life and sent to every flower. Whose most adored name encloses, Things abstruse, deep and divine. Whose yellow tresses shine, Bright as Eoan fire.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: O pure, rich, there is heat in this, on, on.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Bright as Eoan fire, O me thy Priest inspire! For I to thee and thine immortal name --- mark this. In flowing numbers filled with sprite and flame.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Aye marry, there is sprite and flame in this.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: A pox, on this Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Asin.
Hor.
sp.l: For I to thee and thine immortal name, In flowing numbers filled with sprite and flame, To thee Loves mightiest King, Hymen o Hymen does our chaste Muse sing.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: There is music in this;

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mark now dear Asinius. Let these virgins quickly see thee, Leading out the Bride, Though their blushing cheeks they hide, Yet with kisses will they fee thee, To untie their Virgin zone, They grieve to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: So do I by Venus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yet with kisses will they fee thee, my Muse has marched (dear rogue) no farther yet: but how is it? how is it? nay prithee good Asinius deal plainly, do not flatter me, come, how? ---

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: If I have any judgment:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nay look you Sir, and then follow a troop of other rich and laboured conceits, O the end shall be admirable! but how is it sweet Bubo, how, how?

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: If I have any Judgment, it is the best stuff that ever dropped from thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You have seen my Acrostics?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: I will put up my pipes and then I will see anything.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Thou hast a Copy of mine Odes too, hast not Bubo?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Your odes? O that which you spake by word of mouth at the ordinary, when Musco the gull cried Mew at it:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A pox on him poor brainless Rook: and you remember, I told him his wit lay at pawn with his new Satin suit, and both would be lost, for not fetching home by a day.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: At which he would fain have blushed but that his painted cheeks would not let him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nay sirrah the Palinode, which I mean to stitch to my Revels, shall be the best and ingenious piece that ever I sweat for; stay rogue, I will fat thy spleen and make it plump with laughter.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Shall I? faith Ningle, shall I see thy secrets?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Puh my friends.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: But what fardle is that? what fardle is that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Fardle, away, it is my packet; here lies entombed the loves of Knights and Earls, here it is, here it is, here it is, Sir Walter Terils letter to me, and my answer to him: I no sooner opened his letter, but there appeared to me three glorious Angels, whom I adorned, as subjects do their Sovereigns: the honest knight Angles for my acquaintance, with such golden baits --- but why dost laugh my good rogue? how is my answer, prithee, how, how?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l:
Answer, as God judge me Ningle, for thy wit thou 
  mayst answer any Justice of peace in England I warrant; 
    thou writest in a most goodly big hand too, I like that, and readest as legibly as some that 
    have been saved by their neck-verse.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But how dost like the Knights inditing?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: If I have any judgment; a pox on it, here is worshipful lines indeed, here is stuff: but sirrah Ningle, of what fashion is this knights wit, of what block?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Why you see; well, well, an ordinary Ingenuity, a good wit for a knight, you know how, before God I am haunted with some the most pitiful dry gallants.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Troth so I think; good pieces of landscape, show best afar off.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye, aye, aye, excellent sumpter horses, carry good clothes; but honest rogue, come, what news, what news abroad? I have heard of the horses walking on the top of Paules.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Have ye? why the Captain Tucca rails upon you most preposterously behind your back, did you not hear him?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: A pox upon him: by the white and soft hand of Minerua, I will make him the most ridiculous: damn me if I bring not his humourous stage: and --- scurvy limping tongued captain, poor greasy buff Jerkin, hang him: it is out of his Element to traduce me: I am too well ranked Asinius to be stabbed with his dudgeon wit: sirrah, I will compose an Epigram upon him, shall go thus ---

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l:
Nay I have more news, there is Crispinus and his Journeyman Poet Demetrius Faninus too, they swear they will bring
your life and death upon the stage like a Bricklayer in a play.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Bubo they must press more valiant wits than their own to do it: me on the stage? ha, ha, I will start thence poor copper-lace workmasters, that dare play me: I can bring (and that they quake at) a prepared troop of gallants, who for my sake shall distaste every unsalted line, in their fly-blown Comedies

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Nay that is certain, I will bring a hundred gallants of my rank

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That same Crispinus is the silliest Dor, and Faninus the slightest cob-web-lawn piece of a Poet, O God! Why should I care what every Dor doth buzz In credulous ears, it is a crown to me, That the best judgments can report me wronged.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: I am one of them that can report it:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I think but what they are, and am not moved. The one a light voluptuous Reveller, The other, a strange arrogating puff, Both impudent, and arrogant enough.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: 'slid do not Criticus Revel in these lines, ha Ningle ha?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, they are mine own.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Horrace.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Flaccus.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Horrace, not up yet;

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Peace, tread softly, hyde my Papers; who is this so early? Some of my rooks, some of my gulls?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Horrace, Flaccus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Who is there? stray, tread softly: Wat Terill on my life: who is there? my gown sweet rogue, so, come up, come in.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: God morrow Horrace.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O, God save you gallants.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Asinius Bubo well met.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Nay I hope so Crispinus, yet I was sick a quarter of a year ago of a vehement great tooth-ache: a pox on it, it bit me vilely, as God fa me la I knew it was you by your knocking so soon as I saw you; Demetrius Fannius, will you take a whiff this morning? I have tickling gear now, here is that will play with your nose, and a pipe of mine own scouring too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Aye, and a Hogshead too of your own, but that will never be scoured clean I fear.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: I burnt my pipe yesternight, and it was never used since, if you will it is at your service gallants, and Tobacco too, it is right pudding I can tell you; a Lady or two, took a pipe full or two at my hands, and praised it for the Heavens, shall I fill Flannius?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I thank you good Asinius for your love, I seldom take that Physic, it is enough Having so much fool to take him in snuff.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good Bubo read some book, and give us leave, ---

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: Leave have you dear Ningle, marry for reading any book I will take my death upon it (as my Ningle says) it is out of my Element: no faith, ever since I felt one hit me in the teeth that the greatest Clerks are not the wisest men, could I abide to go to School, I was at Ars in presenti and left there: yet because I will not be counted a worse fool than I am, I will turn over a new leaf.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To see my fate, that when I dip my pen In distilled Roses, and do strive to drain, Out of mine Ink all gall; that when I weigh Each syllable I write or speak, because Mine enemies with sharpe and searching eye: Look through and through me, carving my poor labours Like an Anatomy: O heavens to see, That when my lines are measured out as straight As even Parallels, it is strange that still, Still some imagine they are drawn awry. The error is not mine, but in their eye, That cannot take proportions.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l:
Horrace, Horrace, To stand within the shot of galling tongues, Proves not your gilt, for could we write on paper, Made of these turning leaves of heaven, the clouds, Or speak with Angels tongues: yet wise men know, That some would shake the head, though Saints should sing,
Some snakes must hiss, because they are born with stings.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It is true.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Do we not see fools laugh at heaven and mock The Makers workmanship; be not you grieved If that which you mould fair, upright and smooth, Be skewed awry, made crooked, lame and vile, By racking comments, and calumnious tongues, So to be bit it rankles not: for innocence May with a feather brush off the foulest wrongs. But when your dastard wit will strike at men In corners, and in riddles fold the vices Of your best friends, you must not take to heart, If they take off all gilding from their pills, And only offer you the bitter Core.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Crispinus.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l:
Say that you have not sworn unto your Paper, To blot her white cheeks with her dregs and bottom Of your friends private vices: say you swear Your love and your allegiance to bright virtue Makes you descend so low, as to put on The Office of an Executioner, Only to strike off the head of sin, Wherever you find it standing, Say you swear; And make damnation parcel of your oath,
That when your lashing jests make all men bleed; Yet you whip none. Court, City, country, friends, Foes, all must smart alike; yet Court, nor City, Nor foe, nor friend, dare winch at you; great pity.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: If you swear, damn me Faninus, or Crispinus, Or to the law (Our kingdoms golden chain) To Poets damn me, or to Players damn me, If I brand you, or you, tax you, scourge you: I wonder then, that of five hundred, four hundred five, Should all point with their fingers in one instant At one and the same man?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dear Faninus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come, you cannot excuse it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hear me, I can ---

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You must daub on thick colours then to hide it.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: We come like your Physicians, to purge Your sick and dangerous mind of her disease.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: In troth we do, out of our loves we come, And not revenge, but if you strike us still, We must defend our reputations: Our pens shall like our swords be always sheathed, Unless too much provoked, Horace if then They draw blood of you, blame us not, we are men: Come, let thy Muse bear up a smoother sail, It is the easiest and the basest Art to rail.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Deliver me your hands. I love you both, As dear as my own soul, prove me, and when I shall traduce you, make me the scorn of men.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Enough, we are friends.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What reads Asinius?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: By my troth here is an excellent comfortable book, it is most sweet reading in it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Why, what does it smell of Bubo?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Mass it smells of Rose-leaves a little too.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then it must needs be a sweet book, he would fain perfume his ignorance.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: I warrant he had wit in him that penned it.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: It is good yet a fool will confess truth.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: The whoerson made me meet with a hard style in two or three places as I went over him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I believe thee, for they had need to be very low and easy Stiles of wit that thy brains go over.

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.l: Where is this gallant? Morrow Gentlemen: what is this devise done yet Horace?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Gods so, what mean you to let this fellow dog you into my Chamber?

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.l: O, our honest Captain, come, prithee let us see.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Why you bastards of nine whores, the Muses, why do you walk here in this gorgeous gallery of gallant inventions,
with that whoreson poor lime and hair-rascall? why ---

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: O peace good rucca, we are all sworn friends,

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Sworn, that Iudas yonder that walks in Rug, will dub you Knights at the Post, if you serve under his band of oaths, the copper fact rascal will for a good supper out swear twelve dozen of grand Juries.

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.l: A pox on it, not done yet, and been about it three days?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: By Iesu within this hour, save you Captain Tucca.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Damn thee, thou thin bearded Hermaphrodite, damn thee, I will save myself for one I warrant thee, is this thy Tub Diogines?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes Captain this is my poor lodging.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Morrow Captain Tucca, will you whiff this morning?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Art thou there goats pizzle; no god a-mercy Caine I am for no whiffs I, come hither sheep-skin-weaver, 'sfoot thou lookest as though thou hadst begged out of a Jail: draw, I mean not thy face (for it is not worth drawing) but draw near: this way, march, follow your commander you scoundrel: So, thou must run of an errand for me Mephostophiles.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To do you pleasure Captain I will, but whether

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
To hell, thou knowest the way, to hell my fire and
brimstone, to hell; dost stare my Sarfens-head at Newgate? dost gloat? I will march through thy dunkirkes guts, for shooting jests at me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dear Captain but one word.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Out bench-whistler out, I will not take thy word for a dagger Pye: you brown-bread-mouth stinker, I will teach thee to turn me into Bankes his horse, and to tell gentlemen I am a Juggler, and can show tricks.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Captain Tucca, but half a word in your ear.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: No you starved rascal, thou wilt bite off mine ears then, you must have three or four suites of names, when like a lousy Pediculous vermin thou hast but one suite to thy back: you must be called Asper, and Criticus, and Horace, thy title is longer areading than the Style of the big Turkes: Asper, Criticus, Quintus, Horatius, Flacucs.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Captain I know upon what even bases I stand, and therefore ---

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Bases? would the rogue were but ready for me.

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.l: Nay prithee dear Tucca, come you shall shake ---

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Not hands with great Hunks there, not hands, but I will shake the gull-groper out of his tanned skin.

sp.speaker: Crisp. & Deme.
sp.l: For our sake Captain, nay prithee hold.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Thou wrongest here a good honest rascal Crispinus, and a poor varlet Demetrius Fanninus (brethren in
thine own trade of Poetry) thou sayst Crispinus Satin doublet is Reavealed out here, and that this penurious sneaker is out at elbows, go two my good full mouthed ban-dog, I will have thee friends with both.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: With all my heart captain Tucca, and with you too, I will lay my hands under your feet, to keep them from aching.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Can you have any more?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Sayst thou me so, old Coal come? do it then; yet it is no matter neither, I will have thee in league first with these two roly powlies: they shall be thy Damons and thou their Pithyasse; Crispinus shall give thee an old cast Satin suite, and Demetrius shall write thee a Scene or two, in one of thy strong garlic Comedies; and thou shalt take the guilt of conscience for it, and swear it is thine own old lad, it is thine own: thou never yet fellest into the hands of satin, didst?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Never Captain I thank God.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Go to, thou shalt now King Gorboduck, thou shalt, because I will have thee damned, I will have thee all in Satin: Asper, Criticus, Quintus, Horatius, Flaccus, Crispinus shall do it, thou shalt do it, heir apparent of Helicon, thou shalt do it.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Mine Ingle wear an old cast Satin suite?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Aye wafer-face your Ningle.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: If he carry the mind of a Gentleman, he will scorn it at his heels.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Marry muff, my man a ginger-bread, wilt eat any small coal?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: No Captain, would you should well know it, great coal shall not fill my belly.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Scorn it, dost scorn to be arrested at one of his old Suites?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No Captain, I will wear anything.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I know thou wilt, I know thou art an honest low minded Pygmy, for I have seen thy shoulders lapped in a Players old cast Cloak, like a Sly knave as thou art: and when thou rannest mad for the death of Horatio: thou borrowedst a gown of Roscius the Stager, (that honest Nicodemus) and sentest it home lousy, didst not? Responde, didst not?

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.l: So, so, no more of this, within this hour ---

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: If I can sound retreat to my wits, with whom this leader is in skirmish, I will end within this hour.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: What would end? would hang thyself now? has he not writ Finis yet Iacke? what will he be fifteen weeks about this Cockatrices egg too? has he not cackled yet? not laid yet?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Not yet, he swears he will within this hour.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
His wits are somewhat hard bound: the Punk his Muse has sore labour ere the whore be delivered: the poor saffron-cheek Sun-burnt Gypsy wants Physic; give the hungry-faced pudding-pie-eater ten Pills: ten shillings
my fair Angelica, they will make his Muse as yare as a tumbler.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: He shall not want for money if he will write.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Go by Ieronimo, go by; and here, drop the ten shillings into this Basin; do, drop, when Iacke: he shall call me his Moecenas: besides, I will dam up his Oven-mouth for railing at us: So, is it right Iacke? is it sterling? fall off now to the vauward of yonder four Stinkers, and ask aloud if we shall go? the Knight shall defray Iacke, the Knight when it comes to Summa totalis, the Knight, the Knight. ---

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Well Gentlemen, we will leave you, shall we go Captain? good Horrace make some haste.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I will put on wings.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: I never saw mine Ingle so dashed in my life before.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Yes once Asinius.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Mass you say true, he was dashed worse once going (in a rainy day) with a speech to the Tilt-yard, by Gods lid has called him names, a dog would not put up, that had any discretion.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Hold, hold up thy hand, I have seen the day thou didst not scorn to hold up thy golls: there is a Soldiers Spur-royal, twelve pence: Stay, because I know thou canst not write without quicksilver; up again, this goll again, I give thee double press-money: Stay, because I know thou hast a noble head, I will divide my Crown, o royal Porrex, there is a
teston more; go, thou and thy Muse munch, do, munch; come my dear Mandrake, if Skeldering fall not to decay, thou shalt flourish: farewell my sweet Amadis de Gaule, farewell.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dear Captain.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Come Iacke.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Nay Captain stay, we are of your band.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: March fair then:

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Horace farewell, adieu Asinius

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Ningle let us go to some I tavern, and dine together, for my stomach rises at this scurvy leather Captain.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No, they have choked me with mine own disgrace, Which (fools) I will spit again even in your face.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Quintilian Shorthose, Sir Adam, Sir Vaughan, Mineuer with seruingmen.

sp.speaker: Sir quinti.
sp.l: Knaves, Varlets, what Lungis, give me a dozen of stools there.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Jesu bless us all in our five senses a piece, what mean ye sir Kintilian Sorthose to stand so much a dozen stools, here be not breeches enough to hyde a dozen stools, unless you wisse some of us preake his sins.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: I say sir Vaughan no shin shall be broken here: what lungis, a chair with a strong back, and a soft belly, great with child, with a cushion for this reverend Lady.

sp.speaker: Mineu.
sp.l: God never gave me the grace to be a Lady, yet I have been worshipped in my conscience to my face a thousand times, I cannot deny sir Vanghan, but that I have all implements, belonging to the vocation of a Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.l: I trust mistress Mineuer you have all a honest woman should have?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Yes pardy, as my Coach, and my fan, and a man or two that serve my turn, and other things which I would be loath everyone should see, because they shall not be common, I am in manner of a Lady in one point.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.l: I pray mistress Mineuers, let us all see that point for our better understanding.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: For I have some things that were fetched (I am sure) as far as some of the Low Countries, and I paid sweetly for them too, and they told me they were good for Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir qui
sp.l: . And much good do it thy good heart fair widow with them.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I am fair enough to be a Widow, Sir Quintilian.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaug.
sp.l: In my soul and conscience, and well favoured enough to be a Lady: here is sir Kintilian Sorthose, and here is sir Adam Prickshaft, a gentleman of a very good brain, and well headed: you see he shoots his bolt seldom, but when Adam lets go, he hits: and here is sir Vaughan ap Rees, and I believe if God should take us all from his mercy, as I hope he will not yet; we all three love you, at the bottom of our bellies, and our hearts: and therefore mistress Mineuer, if you please, you shall be knighted by one of us, whom you shall desire to put into your device and mind.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: One I must have sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: And one of us thou shalt have widow.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: One I must have, for now everyone seeks to crow over me.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.l: By Jesu and if I find any crowing over you, and he were a cock (come out as far as in Turkeys country) it is possible to cut his comb off.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I muse why sir Adam Prickshaft flies so far from us.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.l: I am in a brown study, my dear, if love should be turned into a beast, what beast he were fit to be turned into.

sp.speaker: Sir quinti.
sp.l: I think Sir Adam an Ass, because of his beating.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I think (saving your reverence) Sir Adam a puppy, for a dog is the most loving creature to a christian that is, unless it be a child.

sp.speaker: Sir Ad.
sp.l: No, I think if love should be turned away, and go to serve any beast, it must be an Ape, and my reason ---

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
Mi.
sp.l:
There is the yawning Captain (saving your reverence that has such a sore mouth) would one day needs persuade
me, that love was a Rebato; and his reason was (saving your reverence) that a Rebato was worn out with pinning too often; and so he said love was.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaugh.
sp.l: And Master Captain Tucca said wisely too, love is a Rebato indeed: a Rebato must be poked; now many women wear Rebatoes, and many that wear Rebatoes ---

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.l: Must be poked.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Sir Adam Prickshaft has hit the clout.

sp.speaker: Sir qui
sp.l: . The Music speaks to us, we will have a dance before dinner.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Walter Terrill, Cælestine, Blunt, Crispinus, and Demetrius, euery one with a Lady.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The King is at hand.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Father the King is at hand. Music talk louder, that thy silver voice, May reach my Sovereigns ears.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaug.
sp.l: I pray do so, Musicians bestir your fingers, that you may have us all by the ears.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: His Grace comes, at Hall varlets, where be my men? blow, blow your cold Trumpets till they sweat; tickle them till they sound again.

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.l: Best go meet his Grace.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.l: Pray all stand bare, as well men as women: Sir Adam is best you hide your head for fear your wise brains take key-cold: on afore Sir Kintilian; Gentleman fall in before the Ladies, in seemly order and fashion; so this is come-eye.

div2.stage: Enter Trumpets sounding, they goe to the doore, and meete the King and his Traine, and whilst the Trumpets sound the King is welcom'd, kisses the Bride, and honors the Bridegroome in dumbe shew.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Nay if your pleasures shrink at sight of us, We shall repent this labour, Mistress Bride You that for speaking but one word today, Must lose your head at night; you that do stand Taking your last leave of virginity; You that being well begun, must not be Maid: Win you the Ladies, I the men will woo, Ourself will lead my blushing Bride with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.l: God bless your Majesty, and send you to be along King William Rufus over us, when he sees his times and pleasures.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: We thank you good Sir Vaughan, we will take your meaning not your words.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: Loud Music there.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: I am glad your Majesty will take anything at my hands; my words I trust in Jesu, are spoken between my soul and body together, and have neither Felonies nor treasons about them, I hope.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Good words Sir Vaughan, I prithee give us leave.

sp.speaker: Vaug.
sp.l:
Good words sir Vaughan? that is by interpretation in english, you are best give good words sir Vaughan: god and his Angels bless me, what ails his majesty to be so tedious and difficult in his right minds now, I hold my life that file rascal-rhymer Horace hath buzzed and buzzed above a hundred merry tales and lice, into his great and princely ears: by god and he
use it, his being Phoebus priest cannot save him, if he were his Sapline too I would press upon his coxcomb: good lord bless me out of his majesties cellar: King Williams, I hope it is none offences to make a supplication to god all mighty for your long life: for by Jesu I have no meaning in it in all the world, unless rascals be here that will have your grace take chalk for cheese, and unless Horace has sent lice to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Horace, what is he sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Vaugh;
sp.l: As hard-favoured a fellow as your majesty has seen in a summers day: he does pen, if it please your grace, toys that will not please your grace; it is a Poet, we call them Bards in our Country, singes ballads and rimes, and I was mighty zealous, that his Ink which is black and full of gall, had brought my name to your majesty, and so lifted up your high and princely choler.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I neither know that Horace, nor mine anger, If as thou sayst our high and princely choler Be up, we will tread it down with dances; Ladies Lose not your men; fair measures must be tread, When by so fair a dancer you are lead.

sp.speaker: Vaugh.
sp.l: Mistress Miniuer:

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Pardy sir Vaughan I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Uaugh.
sp.l: Pardy by this Miniuer cap, and according to his majesty's leave too, you shall be put in among these Ladies, and dance ere long I trust in god, the saking of the seats.

div2.stage: They daunce a straine, and whilst the others keepe on, the King and Celestine stay.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: That turn fair Bride shows you must turn at night, In that sweet dance which steals away delight.

sp.speaker: Cæ.
sp.l: Then pleasure is a thief, a fit, a fever:

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: True, he is the thief, but women the receiver.

div2.stage: Another change; they fall in, the rest goe on.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: This change sweet Maid, says you must change your life, As Virgins do.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Virgins never change their life, She that is wived a maid, is Maid and wife.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: But she that dies a Maid; ---

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Thrice happy then.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Leads Apes in hell.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Better lead Apes than men.

div2.stage: At this third change they end, and she meetes the King.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Well met.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: It is overtaken.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why fair sweet?

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Women are overtaken when they meet;

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Your blood speaks like a coward.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: It were good, If every Maiden blush, had such a blood.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: A coward blood, why whom should maidens fear?

sp.speaker: Cæ.
sp.l: Men, were Maids cowards, they would not come so near, My Lord the Measure is done, I plead my duty.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Only my heart takes measure of thy beauty.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l:
Now by my hose I swear, that is no deep oath, This was a fine sweet earth-quake gently moved,
By the soft wind of whispering Silks: come Ladies, Whose joints are made out of the dancing Orbs, Come, follow me, walk a cold measure now; In the Brides Chamber; your hot beauties melt, Take everyone her fan, give them their places, And wave the Northern wind upon your faces.

div2.stage: Celestine and all the Ladyes doing obeysance to the King, who onely kisses her, Exeunt, Short-hose manning them, the Gallants stand aloofe.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Sir Walter Terrill.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My confirmed Liege

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Beauty out of her bounty, thee hath lent, More than her own with liberal extent.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What means my Lord?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thy Bride, thy choice, thy wife, She that is now thy fathom, thy new world, That brings thee people, and makes little subjects; Kneel at thy feet, obey in everything, So every Father is a private King.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My Lord, her beauty is the poorest part, Chiefly her vertues did endow my heart.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Do not back-bite her beauties, they all shine, Brighter on thee, because the beams are thine, To thee more fair, to others her two lips Show like a parted Moon in thine Eclipse; That glance, which lovers amongst themselves devise, Walks as invisible to others eyes: Give me thine ear.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What means the King?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: It is a quaint strain.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou darest not Wat.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: She is too course an object for the Court.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou darest not Wat: let tonight be tomorrow,

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: For she is not yet mine own.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou darest not Watt:

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My Lord I dare, but ---

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: But I see thou darest not.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: This night.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Yea, this night, tush thy mind repairs not, The more thou talkest of night, the more thou darest not; Thus far I tend, I would but turn this sphere, Of Ladies eyes, and place it in the Court, Where thy fair Bride should for the Zodiac shine, And every Lady else sit for a sign. But all thy thoughts are yellow, thy sweet blood Rebels, thou art jealous Wat; thus with proud revels To emulate the masking firmament, Where Stars dance in the silver Hall of heaven, Thy pleasure should be seasoned, and thy bed Relish thy Bride, But, but thou darest not Wat.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My Lord I dare.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Speak that again.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I dare.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Again kind Wat, and then I know thou darest.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I dare and will by that joint holy oath, Which she and I swore to the book of heaven. This very day when the surveying Sun, Rise like a witness to her faith and mine, By all the loyalty that subjects owe To Majesty, by that, by this, by both, I swear to make a double guarded oath, This night untainted by the touch of man, She shall a Virgin come.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: To Court?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: To Court. I know I took a woman to my wife, And I know women to be earthly Moons, That never shine till night, I know they change Their Orbs (their husbands) and in sickish hearts, Steal to their sweet Endimions, to be cured With better Physic, sweeter diet drinks, Than home can minister: all this I know Yet know not all, but give me leave O King, To boast of mine, and say that I know none; I have a woman but not such a one.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why, she is confirmed in thee; I now approve her, If constant in thy thoughts who then can move her?

sp.speaker: Sir qui
sp.l:
.
Wilt please your Highness take your place within, The Ladies attend the Table.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I go good Knight; Wat thy oath.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My Lord, My oath is my honour, my honour is my life, My oath is constant, so I hope my wife. Exeunt.

div2.stage: Enter Horace in his true attyre, Asinius bearing his Cloake.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: If you fly out Ningle, here is your Cloak; I think it rains too.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Hide my shoulders in it.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Troth so thou hadst need, for now thou art in thy Pee and Kue; thou hast such a villainous broad back, that I warrant thou art able to bear away any man's jests in England.

sp.speaker: Hor.
Asi.
sp.l:
Yes faith, I find my wit at the mending hand Ningle; troth I do not think but to proceed Poetaster next Commencement, if I have my grace perfectly: everyone that confer with me now, stop their nose in merriment and swear I smell somewhat of Horace; one calls me Horaces Ape, another Horaces Beagle, and such Poetical names it passes. I was but at Barbers last day, and when he was rinsing my face, did but cry out, fellow thou makest me Connive too long, and says he says hie, Master Asinius Bubo, you have even Horaces
words as right as if he had spit them into your mouth.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Well, away dear Asinius, deliver this letter to the young Gallant Druso, he that fell so strongly in love with me yesternight.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: It is a sweet Musk-cod, a pure spiced-gull; by this feather I pity his Ingenuities; but hast writ all this since Ningle? I know thou hast a good running head and thou listest.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Foh come, your great bellied wit must long for every thing too; why you Rook, I have a set of letters ready starched to my hands, which to any fresh suited gallant that but newly enters his name into my roll, I send the next morning, ere his ten a clock dream has risen from him, only with clapping my hand to it, that my Novice shall start, ho and his hair stand an end, when he sees the sudden flash of my writing; what you pretty Diminutive rogue, we must have false fires to amaze these spangle babies, these true heirs of Ma. Justice Shallow.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: I would always have thee sauce a fool thus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
Away, and, stay: here be Epigrams upon Tucca, divulge these among the gallants; as for Crispinus, that Crispin-ass and Fannius his Play-dresser; who (to make the Muses believe, their subjects ears were starved, and that there was a dearth of Poesy) cut an Innocent Moore in the middle, to serve him in twice; and when he had done, made Poules-worke of it, as for these Twins these Poet-apes:
Their Mimic tricks shall serve With mirth to feast our Muse, whilst their own starve.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Well Ningle I will trudge, but where is the Randeuow?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Well thought of, marry at Sir Vaughans lodging the Welsh knight, I have composed a love-letter for the gallants worship, to his Rosamond: the second, Mistress Miniuer, because she does not think so soundly of his lame English as he could wish; I have gulled his Knight-ship here to his face, yet have given charge to his winking understanding not to perceive it: nay Gods so, away dear Bubo.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Muses birds the Bees were hived and fled, Us in our cradle, thereby prophesying; That we to learned ears should sweetly sing, But to the vulgar and adulterate brain, Should loath to prostitute our Virgin strain. No, our sharpe pen shall keep the world in awe, Horace thy Poesy, wormwood wreathes shall wear, We hunt not for men's loves but for their fear.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: O Sir Adam Prickshaft, you are at the bow hand wide, a long yard I assure you: and as for Suitors, truly they all go down with me, they have all one flat answer.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.l: All Widow? not all, let Sir Adam be your first man still.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l:
Widow, art stolen from Table? Aye Sir Adam,
Are you my rival? well, fly fair you are best; The King is exceeding merry at the banquet, He makes the Bride blush with his merry words That run into her ears; ah he is a wanton, Yet I dare trust her, had he twenty tongues, And every tongue a Style of Majesty. Now Widow, let me tell thee in thine ear, I love thee Widow, by this ring; nay wear it.

sp.speaker: Mineu.
sp.l: I will come in no rings pardy, I will take no gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.l: Hark in thine ear, take me, I am no gold.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Vaughan and Peter Flash .

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Master Peter Flash, I will grope about Sir Quintilian, for his terminations touching and considering you.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: I thank your Worship, for I have as good a stomach to your Worship as a man could wish.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: I hope in God all mighty, I shall fill your stomach Master Peter: What two upon one Gentleman; Mistress Miniuer, much good do it you Sir Adam.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Sir Vaughan, have you dined well Sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: As good sire as would make any hungry man (if he were in the vilest prison in the world) eat and he had any stomach: One word Sir Quintilian in hugger mugger; here is a Gentleman of yours, Master Peter Flash, is desirous to have his blue coat pulled over his ears; and ---

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l:
No Sir, my petition runs thus, that your worship would thrust me out of doors, and that I may follow Sir
Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: I can tell you Master Flash, if you follow me I go very fast, I think in my conscience, I am one of the lightest knights in England.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: It is no matter Sir, the Flashes have ever been known to be quick and light enough.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Sir Vaughan, he shall follow you, he shall dog you good Sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Why then Peter Flash I will set my four marks a year, and a blue coat upon you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Godamercy to your worship, I hope you shall never repent for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: You bear the face of an honest man, for you blush passing well Peter, I will quench the flame out of your name, and you shall be christened Peter Salamander.

sp.speaker: Peter Flash.
sp.l: The name is too good for me, I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: Are you come Master Horace, you sent me the Copy of your letters countenance, and I did write and read it; your wits truly have done very valiantly: it is a good inditements, you haveput in enough for her have you not?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: According to my instructions.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: It is passing well, I pray Master Horace walk a little beside yourself, I will turn upon you incontinent.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: What Gentleman is this in the Mandilian, a soldier?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: No, though he has a very bad face for a soldier, yet he has as desperate a wit as ever any Scholar went to cuffs for; it is a Gentleman Poet, he has made rimes called Thalamimums, for M. Bridegroom, on word widow.

sp.speaker: Sir qui
sp.l: . Is this he? welcome Sir, your name? pray you walk not so stately, but be acquainted with me boldly; your name Sir?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Quintus, Horacius, Flaccus.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: Good Master Flappus welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Mistress Miniuer, one word in your corner here; I desire you to break my arms here, and read this Paper, you shall feele my minds and affections in it, at full and at large.

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: I will receive no Love libels pardy, but by words of mouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.l: By Jesu it is no libel, for here is my hand to it.

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: I will have no hand in it Sir Vaughan, I will not deal with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: Why then widow, I will tell you by word a mouth my devices.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Your devices come not near my mouth Sir Vaughan pardy, I was upon a time in the way to marriage, but now I am turned on tother side, I have sworn to lead a single and simple life.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.l: She has answered you Sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: It is true, but at wrong weapons Sir Adam; will you be an Ass Mistress Miniuers?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: If I be you shall not ride me.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaug.
sp.l: A simple life! by Jesu it is the life of a fool, a simple life!

sp.speaker: Sir qui
sp.l: . How now Sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Sir Uaugh.
sp.l: My brains has a little fine qualm come under it, and therefore Sir Adam, and Sir Quintilian, and mistress Miniuer caps Good-bye.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Good Sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
Hor.
sp.l: You mean to speak bitterly:

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.l: Right, to spit bitterly upon baldness, or the thinness of hair; you shall eat down Plums to sweeten your mouth, and here is a good Angel to defend you: Peter Salamander follow me.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: With hue and cry and you will Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Come M, Horace, I will go pull out the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And I will set out my wits, Baldness the Theme? My words shall flow high in a silver stream. Exeunt.

div2.stage: Enter Tucca brushing off the crumbes.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Where is my most costly and sumptuous Shorthose?

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: Is the King risen from table Captain Tucca?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: How? risen? no my noble Quintilian, kings are greater men than we Knights and Cavaliers, and therefore must eat more than lesser persons; Godamercy good Diues for these crumbs: how now? has not Friar Tucke dined yet? he falls so hard to that Oyster-pie yonder.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Oyster-pie Captain? ha ha, he loves her, and I love her and fear both shall go without her.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Dost love her, my finest and first part of the Mirror of Knighthood hang her she looks like a bottle of ale, when the cork flies out and the Ale foams at mouth, she looks my good button-breech like the sign of Capricorne, or like Tiborne when it is covered with snow.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: All is one for that, she has a vizard in a bag, will make her look like an Angel; I would I had her, upon condition, gave thee this chain manly Tucca.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Aye? sayst thou so Friskin? I have her at the hip for some causes, I can sound her, she will come at my beck.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Would I could sound her too Noble commander.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Thou shalt do it; that Lady of the Lake is thine Sir Tristram, lend me thy chain, do, lend it, I will make her take it
as a token, I will link her unto thee; and thou shalt wear her glove in thy Worshipful hat like to a leather brooch; Nay and thou mistrusts thy choler, be tied in it still.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Mistrust Captain no here it is, give it her if she will take it, or wear it thyself, if she will take me, I will watch him well enough too.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: No more, I will shoot away yonder Prickshaft, and then belabour her, and fly you after yonder Cuckoo: dost hear me my noble Gold-finch? ---

sp.speaker: Sir qui
sp.l: . No more.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: How dost thou my smug Belimperia how dost thou? hands off my little bald Derricke, hands off: hark hither Susanna, beware of these two wicked Elders, shall I speak well or ill of thee?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Nay, even as you please Captain, it shall be at your choice.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Why well said, my nimble Short-hose.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: I hear her, I hear her.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Art angry father time? art angry because I took mother-Winter aside? I will hold my life thou art struck with Cupids Bird-bolt, my little prickshaft, art? dost love that mother Mumble-crust, dost thou? dost long for that whim-wham?

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.l: Would I were as sure to lie with her, as to love her.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Have I found thee my learned Dunce, have I found
thee? If I might have my will, thou shouldst not put thy spoon into that bumble-broth (for indeed I would taste her myself) no thou shouldst not; yet if her beauty blind thee, she is thine, I can do it, thou heardest her say even now, it should be at my choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.l: She did so, work the match and I will bestow ---

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Not a silk point upon me, little Adam she shall be thy Eve, for less than an Apple; but send, be wise, send her some token, she is greedy, she shall take it, do, send, thou shalt stick in her (Prickeshaft) but send.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.l: Here is a purse of gold, think you that will be accepted?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Go to, it shall be accepted, if it were but silver, when that Flea-bitten Short-hose steppes hence: vanish too, and let me alone with my Grandam in Gutter-Lane there, and this purse of gold do, let me alone

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
Sir Ad.
sp.l: Stay Sir Quintilian I will be a waiter too.

sp.speaker: Sir quinti.
sp.l:
Widow we will trust that Captain there with you.
Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Now, now, mother Bunch how dost thou? what dost flown Queen Gwyniuer? dost wrinkle? what made these pair of Shuttlecocks here? what do they fumble for? I will
have none of these Kites fluttering about thy carcass, for thou shalt be my West Indyes, and none but trim Tucca shall discover thee.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Discover me? discover what thou canst of me.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: What I can? thou knowest what I can discover, but I will not lay thee open to the world.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Lay me open to the world?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: No I will not my mouldy decayed Charing-crosse, I will not.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Hang thee patch-panel, I am none of thy Charing-crosse: I scorn to be Cross to such a scab as thou makest thyself.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: No, it is thou makest me so, my Long Meg a Westminster, thou breedest a scab, thou ---

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I? damn thee filthy Captain, damn thyself.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: My little devil a Tow-gate, I will damn thee, (thou knowest my meaning) I will dam thee up; my wide mouth at Bishops-gate.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Would I might once come to that damming.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Why thou shalt, my sweet dame Annis a clear thou shalt, for I will drown myself in thee; Aye, for thy love, I will sink, I, for thee.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: So thou wilt I warrant, in thy abominable sins; Lord, Lord, how many filthy words hast thou to answer for?.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Name one Madge-owlet, name one, I will answer for none; my words shall be forth coming at all times, and shall answer for themselves; my nimble Cat-a-mountaine: they shall Sislie Bum-trincket, for I will give thee none but Sugar candy words, I will not Puss: goody Tripe-wife, I will not.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Why dost call me such horrible ungodly names then?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I will name thee no more Mother Red-cap upon pain of death, if thou wilt Grimalkin, Maggot-a-pye I will not.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Would thou shouldst well know, I am no Maggot, but a mere Gentlewoman born.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: I know thou art a Gentle, and I will nibble at thee, thou shalt be my Cap-a-maintenance, and I will carry my naked sword before thee, my reverend Lady Lettice-cap.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Thou shalt carry no naked swords before me to fright me, thou ---

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Go to let not thy tongue play so hard at hot-cockles; for, Gammer Gurton, I mean to be thy needle, I love thee, I love thee, because thy teeth stand like the Arches under London Bridge, for thou wilt not turn Satyr and bite thy husband; No, come my little Cub, do not scorn me because I go in Stag, in Buff, here is velvet too; thou seest I am worth thus much in bare velvet.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I scorn thee not, not I.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I know thou dost not, thou shat see that I could march with two or three hundred links before me, look here what? I could show gold too, if that would tempt thee, but I will not make myself a Goldsmiths stall I; I scorn to go chained my Lady at the Hospital, I do; yet I will and must be chained to thee.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: To me? why Master Captain, you know that I have my choice of three or four pair of Knights, and therefore have small reason to fly out I know not how in a man of war.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: A man a war? come thou knowest not what a worshipful vocation it is to be a Captains wife: three or four pair of Knights? why dost hear Ioane-a-bedlam, I will enter into bond to be dubbed by what day thou wilt, when the next action is hyde upon me, thou shalt be Ladyfied.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: You know I am offered that by half a dozen.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Thou shalt little Miniuer, thou shalt, I will have this frock turned into a foot-cloth; and thou shalt be carted, drawn I mean, Coached, Coached, thou shalt ride Jig-Jog; a Hood shall flap up and down here, and this sheepskin-cap shall be put off.

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: Nay pardy, I will put off my cap for no man's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Would thou be proud little Lucifer? well, thou shalt go how thou wilt Maide-marian; come, buss thy little Anthony now, now, my clean Cleopatria; so, so, go thy ways
Alexis secrets, thou hast a breath as sweet as the Rose, that grows by the Bear-garden, as sweet as the proudest head of Garlic in England: come, would march in, to the Gentle folks?

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: Nay truly Captain you shall be my leader.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I say Marry Ambree, thou shalt march foremost, Because I will mark how broad thou art in the heels.

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: Pardy, I will be set at the last for this time.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Why then come, we will walk arm in arm, As though we were leading one another to Newgate.

div2.stage: Enter Blunt, Crispinus, and Demetrius, with papers, laughing.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Mine is of a fashion, cut out quite from yours.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Mine has the sharpest tooth, yonder he is.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Captain Tucca.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: How now? I cannot stand to read supplications now

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: They are bitter Epigrams composed on you By Horace.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And dispersed amongst the gallants In several copies by Asinius Bubo.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: By that live Ecle? read, Lege Legito, read thou lack.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Tucca is grown monstrous, how? rich? that I fear, He is to be seen for money everywhere.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Why true, shall not I get in my debts, nay and the rogue write no better I care not, farewell black Iacke farewell.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: But Captain here is a nettle.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Sting me, do.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Tucca is exceeding tall and yet not high, He fights with skill, but does most vilely lie.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Right, for here I lie now, open, open, to make my adversary come on; and then Sir, here am I in his bosom: nay and this be the worst, I shall hug the poor honest face-maker, I will love the little Atheist, when he writes after my commendation, another whip? come yerk me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Tucca will bite, how? grown Satirical, No, he bites tables, for he feeds on all.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: The whoreson cloven-foot devil in man's apparel lies, There stood above forty dishes before me today, That I never touched, because they were empty.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I am witness young Gentlemen to that.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Farewell stinkers, I smell thy meaning Screech-owle, I do though I stop my nose: and Sirrah Poet, we will have thee untrussed for this; come, mother Mum-pudding, come.

div2.stage: Trumpets sound a florish, and then a sennate: Enter King with Calestine, Sir Walter Terrill, Sir Quintilian, Sir Adam, Blunt and other Ladies and attendants: whilst the Trumpets sound the King takes his leaue of the Bride-groome, and Sir Quintilian, and last of the Bride.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: My song of parting doth this burden bear; A kiss the Ditty, and I set it here. Your lips are well in tune, strung with delight, By this fair Bride remember soon at night: Sir Walter.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My Liege Lord, we all attend, The time and place.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Till then my leave commend.

div2.stage: They bring him to the doore: Enter at another doore Sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l:
Ladies I am to put a very easy suite upon you all,
and to desire you to fill your little bellies at a dinner of plums behind noon; there be Suckets, and Marmalades, and Merchants, and other long white plums that fain would kiss your delicate and sweet lips; I indite you all together, and you especially my Lady Pride; what do you say for yourselves? for I indite you all.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: I thank yon good Sir Vaughan, I will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: Say Gentlemen will you stand to me too?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We will sit with you sweet Sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: God all mighty bless your faces, and make your beauties last, when we are all dead and rotten: --- you all will come.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: All will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Pray God that Horace be in his right wits to rail now.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Come Lady, you shall be my dancing guest. To tread the maze of music with the rest.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will lead you in.

sp.speaker: Dicach.
sp.l: A maze is like a doubt: It is easy to go in, hard to get out.

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.l: We follow close behind.

sp.speaker: Philoca.
sp.l: That measure is best. Now none marks us, but we mark all the rest.

div2.stage: Exeunt all sauing Sir Quintilian, Cælestine, and Sir Walter Terrill.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l:
Father, and you my Bride; that name today, Wife comes not till tomorrow: but omitting
This interchanging of Languages; let us think Upon the King and night, and call our spirits To a true reckoning; first to Arm our wits With complete steel of Judgment, and our tongs, With sound artillery of Phrases: then Our Bodies must be motions; moving first What we speak: afterwards, our very knees Must humbly seem to talk, and suit out speech; For a true furnished Courtier hath such force, Though his tongue faints, his very legs discourse.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Son Terrill, thou hast drawn his picture right, For he is no full-made Courtier, nor well strung, That hath not every joint stuck with a tongue. Daughter, if Ladies say, that is the Bride, that is she, Gaze thou at none, for all will gaze at thee.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Then, o my father must I go? O my husband Shall I then go? O myself, will I go?

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: You must.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You shall.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: I will, but give me leave, To say I may not, nor I ought not, say not Still, I must go, let me entreat I may not.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You must and shall, I made a deed of gift, And gave my oath unto the King, I swore By thy true constancy.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Then keep that word To swear by, O let me be constant still.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What shall I cancel faith, and break my oath?

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: If breaking constancy thou breakest them both.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Thy constancy no evil can pursue.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: I may be constant still, and yet not true.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Cæ.
sp.l: As thus, by violence detained, They may be constant still, that are constrained.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Constrained? that word weighs heavy, yet my oath Weighs down that word; the kings thoughts are at odds, They are not even balanced in his breast; The King may play the man with me; nay more, Kings may usurp; my wife is a woman; yet It is more than I know yet, that know not her, If she should prove mankind, it were rare, fie, fie, See how I lose myself, amongst my thoughts, Thinking to find myself; my oath, my oath.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: I swear another, let me see by what, By my long stocking, and my narrow skirts, Not made to sit upon, she shall to Court. I have a trick, a charm that shall lay down The spirit of lust, and keep thee undeflowered; Thy husbands honour saved, and the hot King, Shall have enough too. Come, a trick, a charm.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: God keep thy honour safe, my blood from harm.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Come, my sick-minded Bride, I will teach thee how, To relish health a little: Taste this thought, That when mine eyes served loves commission, Upon thy beauties I did seize on them. To a Kings use; cure all thy grief with this, That his great seal was graven upon this ring, And that I was but Steward to a King.

div2.stage: A banquet set out: Enter Sir Vaughan, Horace, Asinius Bubo, Lady Petula, Dicache, Philocalia, Mistris Miniuer and Peter Flash .

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.l: Ladies and Gentleman, you are almost all welcome, to this sweet nuncions of Plums.

sp.speaker: Dicach.
sp.l: Almost all Sir Vaughan: why to which of us are you so niggardly, that you cut her out but a piece of welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaugh.
sp.l: My interpretations is that almost all are welcome, because I indicted a brace or two more that is not come, I am sorry my Lady Pride is not among you.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: 'slid, he makes hounds of us Ningle, a brace quoth he?

sp.speaker: Sir Uaug.
sp.l: Peter Salamanders draw out the pictures of all the joint stools, and Ladies sit down upon their wooden faces.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: I warrant Sir, I will give everyone of them a good stool.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Master Horace, Master Horace, when I pray to God, and desire in hipocrisy that bald Sir Adams were here, then, then, then begin to make your rails at the poverty and beggarly want of hair.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Leave it to my judgment.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: M. Bubo sit there, you and I will think upon our ends at the Tables: M. Horace, put your learned body into the midst of these Ladies; so it is no matter to speak graces at nuncions, because we are all past grace since dinner.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Mass I thank my destiny I am not past grace, for by this hand full of Caraways, I could never abide to say grace.

sp.speaker: Dica.
sp.l: Mistress Miniuer, is not that innocent Gentleman a kind of fool?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Why do you ask Madam?

sp.speaker: Dicach.
sp.l: Nay for no harm, I ask because I thought you two had been of acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I think he is within an Inch of a fool.

sp.speaker: Dicach.
sp.l: Madam Philocalia, you sit next that spare Gentleman, would you heard what Mistress Miniuer says of you.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: Why what says she Madam Dicache.

sp.speaker: Dica.
sp.l: Nay nothing, but wishes you were married to that small timbered gallant.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: Your wish and mine are twins, I wish so too for Then I should be sure to lead a merry life.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Yes faith Lady, I would make you laugh, my bolts now and then should be soon shot; by these comfits, we would let all slide.

sp.speaker: Petu.
sp.l:
He takes the sweetest oaths that ever I heard a gallant of his pitch swear; by these Comfits, and these Caraways,
I warrant it does him good to swear.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Yes faith it is meat and drink to me. I am glad Lady Petula (by this Apple) that they please you.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Peter Salamanders wine, I beseech you Master Asinius Bubo, not to swear so deeply, for there comes no fruit of your oaths; here Ladies, I put you all into one corners together, you shall all drink of one cup.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Peter I prithee fill me out too.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: I would fling you out too and I might have my will, a pox of all fools.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Mistress Miniuers, pray be lusty, would Sir Adams Prickshaft stuck by you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Who, the bald Knight Sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
Asi.
sp.l: As God save me la, if I might have my will, I would rather be a bald Gentleman than a hairy; for I am sure the best and tallest Yeomen in England have bald heads: methinks hair is a scurvy lousy commodity.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Bubo, herein you blaze your ignorance.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Pray stop and fill your mouths, and give M. Horace all your ears.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For if of all the bodies parts, the head Be the most royal: if discourse, wit, Judgment, And all our understanding faculties, Sit there in their high Court of Parliament, Enacting laws to sway this humorous world: This little He of Man: needs must that crown, Which stands upon this supreme head, be fair, And held invaluable, and that crown is the Hair: The head that wants this honour stands awry, Is bare in name and in authority.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: He means bald-pates mistress Miniuers.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
Hair, it is the robe which curious nature weaves, To hang upon the head: and does adorn, Our bodies in the first hour we are born: God does bestow that garment: when we die, That (like a soft and silken Canopy) Is still spread over us; In spite of death Our hair grows in our grave, and that alone Looks fresh, when all our other beauty is gone. The excellence of Hair, in this shines clear, That the four Elements take pride to wear The fashion of it: when Fire most bright does burn, The flames to golden locks do strive to turn; When her lascivious arms the Water hurls, About the shores waist, her sleek head she curls:
And torrid clouds being sucked into the Air, When down they melt, hangs like fine silver hair. You see the Earth (whose head so oft it shorn) Frighted to feele her locks so rudely torn, Stands with her hair an end, and (thus afraid) Turns every hair to a green naked blade. Besides, when (struck with grief) we long to die, We spoil that most, which most does beautify, We rend this Head-tyre off. I thus conclude, Colours set colours out; our eyes judge right, Of vice or virtue by their opposite: So, if fair hair to beauty add such grace, Baldness must needs be ugly, and base.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: True M. Horace, for a bald reason, is a reason that has no hairs upon it, a scurvy scalded reason.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: By my truly I never thought you could have picked such strange things out of hair before.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Nay my Ningle can tickle it, when he comes to it.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Troth I shall never be enamelled of a bare-headed man for this, what shift so ever I make.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.l: Then Mistress Miniuer Sir Adams Prickshaft must not hit you; Peter take up all the clothes at the table and the Plums.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Save thee my little worshipful Harper; how do ye
my little cracknels? how do ye?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Welcome M. Tucca, sit and shoot into your belly some Sugar pellets.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: No, Godamercy Cadwallader, how do you Horace?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thanks good Captain.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: Where is the Sering thou carriest about thee? O have I found thee my scouring stick; what is my name Bubo?

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Would I were hanged if I can call you any names but Captain and Tucca.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: No Fye'st, my name is Hamlet revenge: thou hast been at Parris garden hast not?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes Captain, I have played Zulziman there.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Then M. Horace you played the part of an honest man.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Death of Hercules, he could never play that part well in his life, no Fulkes you could not: thou call'st Demetrius Journeyman Poet, but thou puttest up a Supplication to be a poor Journeyman Player, and hadst been still so, but that thou couldst not set a good face upon it: thou hast forgot how thou amblest (in leather pilch) by a play-wagon, in the highway, and tookest mad Ieronimoes part, to get service among the Mimics: and when the Stagerites banished thee into the Isle of Dogs, thou turnedest Ban-dog (villainous Guy) and ever since bitest, therefore I ask if thou hast been at Parris-garden, because thou hast such a good mouth; thou baitest well, read, lege, save thyself and read.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why Captain these are Epigrams composed on you.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Go not out Farthing Candle, go not out, for trusty Damnboys now the deed is done, I will pledge this Epigram in wine, I will swallow in, I, yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: God bless us, will he be drunk with nittigrams now.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: So, now arise sprite at the Buttery; no Herring-bone I will not pull thee out, but arise dear Echo rise, rise devil or I will conjure thee up.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Good Master Tucca let us have no conjuring here.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: Udds blood you scald gouty Captain, why come you to set encumbrances here between the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Be not so tart my precious Metheglin, be not (my old whore of Babilon, sit fast.)

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: O Iesu if I know where abouts in London Babilon stands.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
