sp.l: Feed and be fat my fair Calipolis, stir not my beauteous wriggle-tails, I will disease none of you, I will take none of you up, but only this table-man, I must enter him into some filthy sink point, I must.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Captain, you do me wrong thus to disgrace me.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Thou thinkst thou mayst be as saucy with me as my Buff Jerkin to sit upon me, dost?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Damn me, if ever I traduced your name, What imputation can you charge me with?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: 'sblood, Aye, what computations can you lay to his charge? answer, or by Sefulle canvas your coxcomb Tucky.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: If they draw sweet hearts, let us shift for ourselves.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: My noble swaggerer, I will not fall out with thee, I cannot my mad Comrade, find in my heart to shed thy blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Comrade? by Jesu call me Comrade again, and I will Comrade ye about the sins and shoulders; zounds, what come you to smell out here? did you not dine and feed horribly well today at dinner, but you come to munch here, and give us winter-plums? I pray depart, go marse, marse, marse out adoors.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Adieu Sir Eglamour, adieu Lute-string, Curtain-rod, Goose-quill; here, give that full-nosed Skinker, these rimes; and hark, I will tag my Codpiece point with thy legs, spout-pot I will empty thee.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Dost threaten me? Gods lid I will bind thee to the good forbearing.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Will you amble Hobby-horse, will you trot and amble?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Raw Artichoke I shall sauce thee.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l:
I pray you Master Tucca, will you send me the five pound you borrowed on me; O you cannot hear now, but I will make you hear me and feele me too in another place, to your shame I warrant you, thou shalt not cony-catch me for five pounds; he took it up Sir Vaughan in your name, he
swore you sent for it to Mum withal, it was five pound in gold, as white as my kercher.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.l: zounds, five pound in my name to Mum about withal.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Aye, to Mum withal, but he plays mum-budget with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: Peter Salamander, tie up your great and your little sword, by Jesu I will go sing him while it is hot, I will beat five pound out of his leather pilch: Master Horace, let your wits inhabit in your right places; if I fall sansomely upon the Widow, I have some cousins Garman at Court, shall beget you the reversion of the Master of the Kings Revels, or else be his Lord of Misrule now at Christmas: Come Ladies, whoreson Straggling Captain, I will pound him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How now? what ailest thou, that thou lookest so pale?

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Nay nothing, but I am afraid the Welsh Knight has given me nothing but purging Comfits: this Captain sticks pockily in my stomach; read this scroll, he says they are rimes, and bid me give them you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Rimes it is a challenge sent to you.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: To me?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He says here you divulged my Epigrams.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: And for that dares he challenge me?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You see he dares but dare you answer him?

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: I date answer his challenge, by word of mouth, or by writing, but I scorn to meet him, I hope he and I are not Parallels.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dear Bubo, thou shalt answer him; our credits Lie pawned upon thy resolution, Thy valour must redeem them; charge thy spirits, To wait more close, and near thee: if he kill thee, I will not survive; into one Lottery. We will cast our fates; together live and die.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Content, I owe God a death, and if he will make me pay it against my will, I will say it is hard dealing.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Adam, Tucca, with two pistols by his sides, his boy laden with swords and bucklers.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Did Apolloes Freeze gown watch man (boy, dost hear Turkey-cocks tail have an eye behind, lest the enemy assault our Rearward) on proceed Father Adam; did that same tyrannical-tongued ragamuffin Horace, turn bald-pates out so naked?

sp.speaker: Sir Ad.
sp.l: He did, and whipped them so with nettles, that The Widow swore that a bare-headed man, Should not man her: the Lady Petula Was there, heard all, and told me this.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Go to. Thy gold was accepted, it was, and she shall bring thee into her Paradise, she shall small Adam, she shall.

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.l: But how? but how Captain?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Thus, go, cover a table with sweet meats, let all the
Gentlewomen, and that same Pasquils-mad-cap (mother Bee there) nibble, bid them bite: they will come to gobble down Plums; then take up that pair of Basket hilts, with my commission, I mean Crispinus and Fannius; charge one of them to take up the Bucklers, against that hair-monger Horace, and have a bout or two, in defence of bald-pates: let them crack every crown that has hair on it: go, let them lift up baldness to the sky, and thou shalt see, it will turn Miniuers heart quite against the hair.

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.l: Excellent, why then M. Tucca ---

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Nay, whir, nimble Prickshaft; whir, away, I go upon life and death, away, fly Scanderbag fly.

div2.stage: Enter Asinius Bubo, and Horace aloofe.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Arm Captain, arm, arm, arm, the foe is come down.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Hold Captain Tucca hold, I am Bubo, and come to answer anything you can lay to my charge.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
Asin.
sp.l: Use me how you will; I am resolute, for I have made my Will.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Wilt fight Turke-a-ten-pence? wilt fight then?

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: Thou shalt find I will fight in a Godly quarrel, if I be once fired.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Thou shalt not want fire, I will have thee burnt when thou wilt, my cold Cornelius: but come: Respice funem; look, thou seest; open thyself my little Cutlers Shop, I challenge thee thou slender Gentleman, at four sundry weapons.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: Thy challenge was but at one, and I will answer but one.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Thou shalt answer two, for thou shalt answer me and my Captain.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Well said Cockerel out-crow him: art hardy noble Huon? art Magnanimous? lick-trencher; look, search lest some lie in ambush; for this man at Arms, has paper in his belly, or some friend in a corner, or else he durst not be so crank.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Captain, Captain, Horace stands sneaking here.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I smelt the foul-fisted Mortar-treader, come my most damnable fastidious rascal, I have a suite to both of you.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.l: O hold, most pitiful Captain hold.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hold Captain, it is known that Horace is valiant, and a man of the sword.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
A Gentleman or an honest Citizen, shall not Sit in your penny-bench Theatres, with his Squirrel by his side cracking nuts; nor sneak into a Tavern with his Mermaid; but he shall be Satired, and Epigrammed upon, and his humour must run upon the Stage: you will have Every Gentleman in his humour,
and Every Gentleman out of his humour: we that are heads of Legions and Bands, and fear none but these same shoulder-clappers, shall fear you, you Serpentine rascal.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Honoured Captain.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Art not famous enough yet my mad Horastratus, for killing a Player, but thou must eat men alive? thy friends? Sirrah wild-man, thy Patrons? thou Anthropophagite, thy Mecænasses?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Captain, I am sorry that you lay this wrong. So close unto your heart: dear Captain think I writ cut of hot blood, which (now) being cold, I could be pleased (to please you) to quaff down, The poisoned Ink, in which I dipped your name.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Sayst thou so, my Palinodical timester?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hence forth I will rather breath out Solecisms (To do which I would as soon speak blasphemy) Than with my tongue or pen to wound your worth, Believe it noble Captain; it to me Shall be a Crown, to crown your acts with praise, Out of your hate, your love I will strongly raise.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
I know now thou hast a number of these Quiddits to bind men to the peace: it is thy fashion to flirt Ink in every man's face; and then to crawl into his bosom, and damn thyself to wipe it off again: yet to give out abroad, that he was
glad to come to composition with thee: I know Monsieur Machiauell it is one of thy rules; My long-heeled Troglodite, I could make thine ears burn now, by dropping into them, all those hot oaths, to which, thyself gavest voluntary fire, (when thou wast the man in the Moon) that thou wouldst never squib out any new Salt-peter Jests against honest Tucca, nor those Maligo-tasters, his Poetasters; I could Cinocephalus, but I will not, yet thou knowest thou hast broke those oaths in print, my excellent infernal.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Nay I smell what breath is to come from thee, thy answer is, that there is no faith to be held with Heretics and Infidels, and therefore thou swearest anything: but come lend me thy hand, thou and I hence forth will be Alexander and Lodwicke, the Gemini: sworn brothers, thou shalt be Perithous and Tucca Theseus; but I will leave thee in the lurch, when thou makest thy voyage into hell: till then, Thine-assuredly.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: With all my soul dear Captain.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Thou wilt shoot thy quills at me, when my terrible back is turned for all this, wilt not Porcupine? and bring me and my Heliconistes into thy Dialogues to make us talk madly, would not Lucian?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Captain, if I do ---

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Nay and thou dost, horns of Lucifer, the parcel-poets shall Sue thy wrangling Muse, in the Court of Pernassus,
and never leave hunting her, till she plead in Forma Pauperi: but I hope thou hast more grace: come: friends, clap hands it is a bargain; amiable Bubo, thy fist must walk too: so, I love thee, now I see thou art a little Hercules, and wilt fight; I will Stick thee now in my company like a sprig of Rosemary.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Reesap Vaughan and Peter Flash.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Draw Sir Rees he is yonder, shall I upon him?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Upon him? go too, go too Peter Salamander; hold, in Gods name hold; I will kill him to his face, because I mean he shall answer for it; being an eye-witness; one word Captain Tucky.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I will give thee ten thousand words and thou wilt, my little Thomas Thomasius.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
Tuc.
sp.l: Thou shalt have five, and five, and five and thou wantest money my Job.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Leave your fetches and your fegaries, you tough leather jerkin; leave your quandaries, and tricks, and draw upon me you are best: you cony-catch Widow Miniuer-caps for five pounds, and say it is for me to cry Mum, and make me run up and down in dishonours, and discredits; is it not true, you winke-a-pipes rascal? is not true?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Right, true, guilty, I remember it now; for when I spake a good word to the Widow for thee my young Sampson ---

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: For five pounds you cheating scab, for five pounds, not for me.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: For thee o Cæsar, for thee I took up five pounds in gold, that lay in her lap, and said I would give it thee as a token from her: I did it but to smell out how she stood affected to thee, to feele her; I, and I know what she said, I know how I carried away the gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: By Jesu, I have not the mercy to fall upon him now: M. Tucky, did widow Miniuers part quietly from her gold, because you lied, and said it was for me?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Quietly, in peace, without grumbling; made no noise, I know how I tempted her, in thy behalf; my little Trang do.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Captain Tucky, I will pay back her five pounds (unless you be damned in lies) and hold you, I pray you pocket up this; by the cross of this sword and dagger, Captain you shall take it.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Dost swear by daggers? nay then I will put up more at thy hands than this.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: Is the fray done sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Done Peter, put up your smeeter.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Come hither, my sour-faced Poet; fling away that beard-brush Bubo, cashier him and hark: Knight attend: So, that raw-head and bloody-bones Sir Adam, has fee-ed another brat (of those nine common wenches) to defend baldness and to rail against hair: he will have a fling at thee, my noble Cock-Sparrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: At me? will he sling the cudgels of his wit at me?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: And at thy button-cap too; but come, I will be your leader you shall stand, hear all, and not be seen; cast off that blue coat away with that flawn, and follow, come:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Bubo, we follow Captain.

sp.speaker: Sir Ua
sp.l: Peter, leave coming behind me, I pray any longer for you and I must part Peter.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: Sounds Sir, I hope you will not serve me so, to turn me away in this case.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: Turn you into a fools coat; I mean I will go solus, or in solitaries alone; zounds you are best give better words, or I will turn you away indeed; where is Captain Tucky? come Horace; get you home Peter.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.l: I will home to your cost, and I can get into the Wine-Seller.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Remember where to meet me.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Yes I will meet; Tucca should have found I dare meet.

sp.speaker: Ho.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Adam, Crispinus, Fannius, Blunt, Miniuer, Petula, Philocalia and Dicace .

sp.speaker: Ladies,
sp.l: Thanks good Sir Adam.

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.l: Welcome red-cheeked Ladies, And welcome comely Widow; Gentlemen, Now that our sorry banquet is put by, From stealing more sweet kisses from your lips Walk in my garden: Ladies let your eyes Shed life into these flowers by their bright beams, Sit, Sit here is a large bower, here all may hear, Now good Crispinus let your praise begin. There, where it left off Baldness.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I shall win. No praise, by praising that, which to deprave, All tongues are ready, and which none would have.

sp.speaker: Bin.
sp.l: To prove that best, by strong and armed reason, Whose part reason fears to take, cannot but prove, Your wit is fine temper, and from these win love.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I promise you has almost converted me, I pray bring forward your bald reasons M. Poet.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l:
Mistress you give my Reasons proper names, For Arguments (like Children) should be like, The subject that begets them; I must strive To crown Bald heads, therefore must baldly thrive; But be it as it can: To what before, Went armed at table, this force bring I more, If a Bare head (being like a deadman's skull) Should bear up no praise else but this, it sets
Our end before our eyes; should I despair, From giving Baldness higher place than hair?

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: Nay pardy, hair has the higher place.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: The goodliest and most glorious strange-built wonder, Which that great Architect hath made, is heaven; For there he keeps his Court, It is his Kingdom, That is his best Master-piece; yet it is the roof, And Ceiling of the world: that may be called The head or crown of Earth, and yet that is bald, All creatures in it bald; the lovely Sun, Has a face sleek as gold; the full-cheeked Moon, As bright and smooth as silver: nothing there Wears dangling locks, but sometime blazing Stars, Whose flaming curls set realms on fire with wars. Descend more low; look through man's five-fold sense, Of all, the Eye, bears greatest eminence; And yet that is bald, the hairs that like a lace, Are stiched unto the lids, borrow those forms, Like Pent-houses to save the eyes from storms.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.l: Right, well said.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l:
A head and face overgrown with Shaggy dross, O, it is an Orient pearl hid all in Moss, But when the head is all naked and uncrowned, It is the worlds Globe, even, smooth and round; Baldness is natures But, at which our life,
Shoots her last Arrow: what man ever lead His age out with a staff, but had a head Bare and uncovered? he whose years do rise, To their full height, yet not bald, is not wise. The Head is Wisdoms house, Hair but the thatch, Hair? It is the basest stubble; in scorn of it, This Proverb sprung, he has more hair than wit: Mark you not in derision how we call, A head grown thick with hair, Bush-natural?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: By your leave (Master Poet) but that Bush-natural, is one of the trimmest, and most entanglingest beauty in a woman.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Right, but believe this ( pardon me most fair ) You would have much more wit, had you less hair: I could more weary you to tell the proofs. (As they pass by) which fight on Baldness side, Than were you tasked to number on a head, The hairs: I know not how your thoughts are lead, On this strong Tower shall my opinion rest, Heads thick of hair are good, but bald the best,

div2.stage: Whilst this Paradox is in speaking, Tucca Enters with Sir Vaughan at one doore, and secretly placeth him: then Exit and brings in Horace muffled, placing him: Tucca sits among them.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Thou art within a hair of it, my sweet Wit whether wile thou? my delicate Poetical Fury, thou hast hit it to a hair.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l:
By your favour Master Tucky, his bald reasons are wide above two hairs, I beseech you pardon me Ladies, that I thrust in so malepartly among you, for I did but much hear, and see how this cruel Poet did handle bald
heads.

sp.speaker: Sir Ad.
sp.l: He gave them but their due Sir Vaughan; Widow did he not?

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: By my faith he made more of a bald head, than ever I shall be able: he gave them their due truly.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaugh.
sp.l: Nay uds blood, their due is to be of the right hair as I am, and that was not in his fingers to give, but in God all mighty's: Well, I will hire that humorous and fantastical Poet Master Horace, to break your bald pate Sir Adam.

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.l: Break my bald pate?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Dost hear my worshipful block-head?

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.l: Patience Captain Tucky, let me absolve him; I mean he shall prick, prick your head or sconce a little with his goose-quills, for he shall make another Thalimum, or cross-sticks, or some Polinoddyes, with a few Nappy-grams in them, that shall lift up hair, and set it an end, with his learned and hearty commendations.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This is excellent, all will come out now.

sp.speaker: Dica.
sp.l:
That same Horace methinks has the most ungodly face, by my Fan; it looks for all the world, like a rotten russet Apple, when it is bruised: It is better than a spoonful of Cinnamon water next my heart, for me to hear him speak; he sounds it so in the nose, and talks and rants for all the world, like the poor fellow under Ludgate: O fie upon
him.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: By my troth sweet Ladies, it is Cake and pudding to me, to see his face make faces, when he reads his Songs and Sonnets.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I will face some of you for this, when you shall not budge.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: It is the stinkingest dung-farmer --- foh upon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: Foh? zounds you make him worse than old herring: foh? by Jesu I think he is as tidy, and as tall a Poet as ever drew out a long verse.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: The best verse that ever I knew him hack out, was his white neck verse: noble Ap Rees thou wouldst scorn to lay thy lips to his commendations, and thou smelledest him out as I do, he calls thee the burning Knight of the Salamander.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaugh.
sp.l: Right, Peter is my Salamander; what of him? but Peter is never burnt: how now? so, go too now.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.l: And says because thou Clippest the Kings English.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.l: Zounds me? that is treason: clip? horrible treasons, Jesu hold my hands; clip? he baits mousetraps for my life.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.l: Right little Twinkler, right: he says because thou speakest no better, thou canst not keep a good tongue in thy head.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.l:
By God it is the best tongue, I can buy for love
or money.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: He shoots at thee too Adam Bell, and his arrows sticks here; he calls thee bald-pate.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaugh.
sp.l: Zounds make him prove these intolerabilities.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: And asks who shall carry the vinegar-bottle? and then he rimes to it, and says Prickshaft: nay Miniuer he crumples thy Cap too; and ---

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Come Tucca, come, no more; the man is well known, thou needst not paint him, whom does he not wrong?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Marry himself, the ugly Pope Boniface, pardons himself, and therefore my judgment is, that presently he be had from hence, to his place of execution, and there be Stabbed, Stabbed, Stabbed.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O gentlemen, I am slain, O slave art hired to murder me, to murder me, to murder me?

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: O God!

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.l: zounds Captain you have put all Poetry to the dint of sword, blow wind about him: Ladies for our Lords sake you that have smocks, tear off pieces to shoot through his Zounds: Is he dead and buried is he? pull his nose, pinch, rub, rub, rub, rub.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: If he be not dead, look here; I have the Stab and pippin for him: if I had killed him, I could have pleased the great fool with an Apple.

sp.speaker: Cris.
Sir Vau.
sp.l: I am glad M. Horace, to see you walking.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I am black and blue the breadth of a groat.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Breadth of a groat? there is a teston, hide thy infirmities, my scurvy Lazarus; do, hide it, lest it prove a scab in time: hang thee desperation, hang thee, thou knowest I cannot be sharpe set against thee: look, feele (my light-uptails all) feele my weapon.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: O most pitiful as blunt as my great thumb.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: By Jesu, as blunt as a Welsh bag-pudding.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: As blunt as the top of Poules; it is not llike thy Aloe, Cicatrine tongue bitter: no it is no stabber but like thy goodly and glorious nose, blunt, blunt, blunt: dost roar bulchin? dost roar? thou hast a good rouncival voice to cry Lantern and Candle-light.

sp.speaker: Sir Va.
Hor.
sp.l: Sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Va.
sp.l: You lie sir varlet sir villain, I am sir Salamanders, zounds, is my man Master Peter Salamanders face as worse as mine? Gentleman, all and Ladies, and you say once or twice Amen, I will lap this little Silde, this Booby in his blankets again.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: A blanket, these cracked Venice glasses shall fill him out, they shall toss him, hold fast wag-tails: so, come, in, take this bandy with the racket of patience, why when? dost flampe mad Tamberlaine, dost stamp? thou thinkest thou hast Mortar under thy feet, dost?

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: Come, a bandy ho.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O hold most sacred beauties.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Hold, silence, the puppet-teacher speaks.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Sir Vaughan, noble Captain, Gentlemen, Crispinus, dear Demetrius o redeem me, Out of this infamous --- by God by Iesu ---

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Nay, swear not so good Horace, now these Ladies, Are made your executioners: prepare, To suffer like a gallant, not a coward; I will try to unloose, their hands, impossible. Nay, women's vengeance are implacable.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why, would you make me thus the ball of scorn?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
I will tell thee why, because thou hast entered Actions of assault and battery, against a company of honourable and worshipful
Fathers of the law: you wrangling rascal, law is one of the pillars of the land, and if thou beest bound to it (as I hope thou shalt be) thou wilt prove a skip-jack, thou wilt be whipped. I will tell thee why, because thy sputtering chaps yelp, that Arrogance, and impudence, and Ignorance, are the essential parts of a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: You remember Horace they will punk, and pink, and pump you, and they catch you by the coxcomb: on I pray, one lash, a little more.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I will tell thee why because thou cryest ptrooh at worshipful Citizens, and callest them Flat-caps, Cuckolds, and bankrupts, and modest and virtuous wives punks and cockatrices. I will tell thee why, because thou hast arraigned two Poets against all law and conscience; and not content with that, hast turned them amongst a company of horrible black Friars.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: The same hand still, it is your own another day, M. Horace, admonitions is good meat.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
Hor.
sp.l:
What could I do, out of a just revenge,
But bring them to the Stage? they envy me because I hold more worthy company.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Good Horace, no; my cheeks do blush for thine, As often as thou speakest so, where one true And nobly-virtuous spirit, for thy best part Loves thee, I wish one ten, even from my heart. I make account I put up as deep share In any good man's love which thy worth earns, As thou thyself; we envy not to see, Thy friends with Bays to crown thy Poesy. No, here the gall lies, we that know what stuff Thy very heart is made of; know the stalk On which thy learning grows, and can give life To thy (once dying) baseness; yet must we Dance Antics on your Paper.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Fannius.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: This makes us angry, but not envious, No, were thy warped soul, put in a new mould, I would wear thee as a Jewel set in gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: And Jewels Master Horace, must be hanged you know.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Good Pagans, well said, they have sowed up that broken seam rent lie of thine, that Demetrius is out at Elbows, and Crispinus is fallen out with Satin here, they have; but bloat-herring dost hear?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes honoured Captain, I have ears at will.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Is it not better be out at Elbows, than to be a bond slave, and to go all in Parchment as thou dost?

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.l: Parchment Captain? it is Perpetuana I assure you.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: My Perpetual pantaloon true, but it is waxed over; thou art made out of Wax; thou must answer for this one day; thy Muse is a haggler, and wears clothes upon best-be-trust: thou art great in somebody's books for this, thou knowest where; thou wouldst be out at Elbows, and out at heels too, but that thou layest about thee with a Bill for this, a Bill ---

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I confess Captain, I followed this suite hard.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I know thou didst, and therefore whilst we have Hiren here, speak my little dish-washers, a verdit Pissekitchins.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Blanket.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Hold I pray, hold, by Jesu I have put upon my head, a fine device, to make you laugh, it is not your fools Cap Master Horace, which you covered your Poetasters in, but a fine trick, ha, ha, is jumbling in my brain.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I will beat out thy brains, my whoreson handsome dwarf, but I will have it out of thee.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: What is it good Sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l:
To conclude, it is after this manners, because Ma. Horace is ambition, and does conspire to be more high and
tall as God all mighty made him, we will carry his terrible, person to Court, and there before his Majesty Dub, or what you call it, dip his Muse in some liquor, and christen him, or dye him, into colours of a Poet.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Super Super-excellent Revellers go, proceed you Masters of Art in kissing these wenches, and in dances, bring you the quivering Bride to Court, in a Mask, come Grumboll, thou shalt Mum with us; come, dog me skneakes-bill.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O thou my Muse!

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Call upon God all mighty, and no Muses, your Muse I warrant is otherwise occupied, there is no dealing with your Muse now, therefore I pray marse, marse, marse, Zounds your Moose?

sp.speaker: Cri
sp.l: We shall have sport to see them; come bright beauties, The Sun stoops low, and whispers in our ears, To hasten on our Mask, let us crown this night, With choice composed wreathes of sweet delight. Exeunt.

div2.stage: Enter Terrill and Cælestine sadly, Sir Quintilian stirring and migling a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l:
O Night, that Dyes the Firmament in black, And like a cloth of clouds dost stretch thy limbs; Upon the windy Tenters of the Air: O thou that hangest upon the back of Day, Like a long mourning gown: thou that art made Without an eye, because thou shouldst not see A Lovers Revels: nor participate
The Bridegrooms heaven; o heaven, to me a hell: I have a hell in heaven, a blessed curse; All other Bridegrooms long for Night, and tax The Day of lazy sloth; call Time a Cripple, And say the hours limp after him: but I Wish Night for ever banished from the sky, Or that the Day would never sleep: or Time, Were in a swoon; and all his little Hours, Could never lift him up with their poor powers.
But backward runs the course of my delight; The day hath turned his back, and it is night: This night will make us odd; day made us even, All else are damned in hell, but I in heaven.

sp.speaker: Cæ.
sp.l: Let loose thy oath so shall we still be even.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Then am I damned in hell, and not in heaven.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
Ter.
sp.l: Had I not sworn.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Why didst thou swear?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l:
The King Sat heavy on my resolution,
Till (out of breath) it panted out an oath.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: An oath? why, what is an oath? it is but the smoke, Of flame and blood; the blister of the spirit, Which riseth from the Steam of rage, the bubble That shoots up to the tongue, and scalds the voice, (For oaths are burning words) thou sworest but one, It is frozen long ago: if one be numbered, What Countrymen are they? where do they dwell, That speak naught else but oaths?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: They are men of hell. An oath? why it is the traffic of the foul, It is law within a man; the seal of faith, The bond of every conscience; unto whom, We set our thoughts like hands: yea, such a one I swore, and to the King: A King contains A thousand thousand; when I swore to him, I swore to them; the very hairs that guard His head, will rise up like sharpe witnesses Against my faith and loyalty: his eye Would straight condemn me: argue oaths no more, My oath is high, for to the King I swore.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Quintilian with the cup.

sp.speaker: Cæ.
sp.l: Must I betray my Chastity? So long Clean from the treason of rebelling lust; O husband! O my Father! if poor I. Must not live chaste, then let me chastely die.

sp.speaker: S. qui.
sp.l: Aye, here is a charm shall keep thee chaste, come, come, Old Time hath left us but an hour to play Our parts; begin the Sceane, who shall speak first? O, I, I play the King, and Kings speak first; Daughter stand thou here, thou Son Terrill there, O thou standest well thou I leanest against a post, (For thou wilt be posted off I warrant thee:) The King will hang a horn about thy neck, And make a post of thee; you stand well both, We need no Prologue, the King entering first, He is a most gracious Prologue: marry then For the Catastrophe, or Epilogue, There is one in cloth of Silver, which no doubt, Will please the hearers well when he steps out; His mouth is filled with words: see where he stands; He will make them clap their eyes besides their hands. But to my part; suppose who enters now, A King, whose eyes are set in Silver; one That blusheth gold, speaks Music dancing walks, Now gathers nearer takes thee by the hand, When straight thou thinkst, the very Orb of heaven, Moves round about thy fingers, then he speaks, Thus --- thus --- I know not how.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Nor I to answer him.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l:
No girl: knowest thou not how to answer him?
Why then the field is lost, and he rides home, Like a great conqueror; not answer him? Out of thy part already? foiled the Sceane? Disranked the lines? disarmed the action?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Yes yes, true chastity is tongued so weak, It is overcome ere it know how to speak.

sp.speaker: Sir qui
sp.l: . Come, come, thou happy close of every wrong, It is thou that canst dissolve the hardest doubt; It is time for thee to speak, we are all out. Daughter, and you the man whom I call Son, I must confess I made a deed of gift; To heaven and you, and gave my child to both: When on my blessing I did charm her soul, In the white circle of true Chastity, Still to run true, till death: now Sir if not, She forfeits my rich blessing, and is Fined With an eternal curse; then I tell you, She shall die now, now whilst her soul is true.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Die?

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Aye, I am deaths echo.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l:
O my Son, I am her Father; every tear I shed, Is threescore ten year old; I weep and smile Two kind of tears: I weep that she must die, I smile that she must die a Virgin: thus
We joyful men mock tears, and tears mock us.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What speaks that cup?

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: White wine and poison.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: O: That very name of poison, poisons me; Thou Winter of a man thou walking grave, Whose life is like a dying Taper: how Canst thou define a Lovers labouring thoughts? What Sent hast thou but death? what taste but earth? The breath that purls from thee, is like the Steam Of a new-opened vault: I know thy drift, Because thou art travelling to the land of Graves, Thou covetest company, and hither bringest, A health of poison to pledge death: a poison For this sweet spring; this Element is mine, This is the Air I breath; corrupt it not; This heaven is mine, I bought it with my soul, Of him that sells a heaven, to buy a soul.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l:
Well, let her go; she is thine thou callest her thine, Thy Element, the Air thou breathest; thou knowest The Air thou breathest is common, make her so: Perhaps thou wilt say; none but the King shall wear Thy nightgown, she that laps thee warm with love; And that Kings are not common: Then to show, By consequence he cannot make her so,
Indeed she may promote her shame and thine, And with your shames, speak a good word for mine: The King shining so clear, and we so dim, Our dark disgraces will be seen through him. Imagine her the cup of thy moist life, What man would pledge a King in his own wife?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: She dies: that sentence poisons her: O life! What slave would pledge a King in his own wife?

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Welcome, o poison physic against lust, Thou wholesome medicine to a constant blood; Thou rare Apothecary that canst keep, My chastity preserved, within this box; Of tempting dust, this painted earthen pot, That stands upon the stall of the white soul, To set the shop out like a flatterer, To draw the customers of Sin: come, come, Thou art no poison, but a diet-drink, To moderate my blood: White-innocent Wine, Art thou made guilty of my death O no, For thou thyself art poisoned, take me hence, For Innocence, shall murder Innocence.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l:
Hold, hold, thou shalt not die, my Bride, my wife, O stop that speedy messenger of death; O let him not run down that narrow path, Which leads unto thy heart; nor carry news
To thy removing soul, that thou must die.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: It is done already, the Spiritual Court, Is breaking up; all Offices discharged, My soul removes from this weak standing house, Of frail mortality: Dear Father, bless Me now and ever: Dearer Man farewell, I jointly take my leave of thee and life, Go, tell the King thou hast a constant wife.

sp.speaker: Ter.
Sir quin.
sp.l: Yea smiles on my cheeks arise, To see how sweetly a true virgin dies.

div2.stage: Enter Blunt, Crispinus, Fannius, Philocalia, Dicache, Petula, lights before them.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Sir Walter Terrill, gallants are all ready,

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: All ready.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Well said, come, come, where is the Bride?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: She is going to forbid the Banes again. She will die a maid: and see, she keeps her oath.

sp.speaker: All the men.
sp.l: Fair Cælestine!

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: The Bride!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: She that was fair, Whom I called fair and Cælestine.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Dead, she is death's Bride, he hath her maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Sir Walter Terrill.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Tell us how.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: All cease, The subject that we treat of now is Peace, If you demand how: I can tell: if why, Ask the King that; he was the cause, not I. Let it suffice, she is dead, she kept her vow, Ask the King why, and then I will tell you how: Nay give your Revels life, though she be gone, To Court with all your preparation; Lead on, and lead her on; if any ask The mystery, say death presents a mask, Ring peals of Music, you are Lovers bells, The loss of one heaven, brings a thousand hells. Exeunt.

div2.stage: Enter an arm'd Sewer, after him the seruice of a Banquet: the King at another doore meetes them, they Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why so, even thus the Mercury of Heaven, Ushers the ambrosiate banquet of the Gods, When a long train of Angels in a rank, Serve the first course, and bow their Crystal knees, Before the Silver table; where Ioues page Sweet Ganimed fills Nectar: when the Gods. Drink healths to Kings, they pledge them; none but Kings Dare pledge the Gods, none but Gods drink to Kings. Men of our house are we prepared?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Liege, All wait the presence of the Bride.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l:
The Bride?
Yea, every senseless thing, which she beholds, Will look on her again her eyes reflection, Will make the walls all eyes, with her perfection: Observe me now, because of Masks and Revels, And many nuptial ceremonies: Mark, This I create the Presence here the State, Our Kingdoms seat, shall sit in honours Pride, Like pleasures Queen, there will I place the Bride: Be gone, be speedy, let me see it done.
A King in Love, is Steward to himself, And never scorns the office, myself buy, All glances from the Market of her eye.
sp.stage: Soft Music, chair it set under a Canopy.
sp.l: Sound Music, thou sweet suitor to the air, Now woo the air again this is the hour, Writ in the Calendar of time, this hour, Music shall spend, the next and next the Bride; Her tongue will read the music-lecture: Wat I love thee Wat, because thou art not wise; Not deep-read in the volume of a man, Thou never sawest a thought, poor soul thou thinkst, The heart and tongue is cut out of one piece, But thou art deceived, the world hath a false light, Fools think it is day, when wise men know it is night.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: My Liege they are come a mask of gallants,

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Now --- the spirit of Love ushers my blood.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: They come. The Watch-word in a Mask is the bold Drum.

div2.stage: Enter Blunt, Crispinus, Demetrius, Philocalia, Petula, Dicache, all maskt, two and two with lights like maskers: Cælestine in a chaire.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: All pleasures guard my King, I here present, My oath upon the knee of duty: knees Are made for Kings, they are the subjects Fees.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Wat Terrill thou art ill suited, ill made up, In Sable colours, like a night piece dyed, Comest thou the Prologue of a Mask in black; Thy body is ill shaped; a Bridegroom too? Look how the day is dressed in Silver cloth, Laid round about with golden Sunbeams: so (As white as heaven) should a fresh Bridegroom go. What? Cælestine the Bride, in the same task? Nay then I see there is mystery in this mask. Prithee resolve me Wat?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, That part is hers, she acts it; only I Present the Prologue, she the mystery.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Come Bride, the Sceane of blushing entered first, Your cheeks are settled now, and past the worst;
A mystery? O none plays here but death, This is deaths motion, motionless; speak you, Flatter no longer; thou her Bridegroom; thou Her Father speak.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Poisoned.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: And poisoned? What villain durst blaspheme her beauties, or Profane the clear religion of her eyes.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l:
Now King I enter, now the Sceane is mine, My tongue is tipped with poison; know who speaks, And look into my thoughts; I blush not King, To call thee Tyrant: death hath set my face, And made my blood bold; hear me spirits of men, And place your ears upon your hearts; the day (The fellow to this night) saw her and me, Shake hands together: for the book of heaven, Made us eternal friends: thus, Man and Wife, This man of men (the King) what are not kings? Was my chief guest, my royal guest, his Grace Graced all the Table, and did well become The upper end, where sate my Bride: in brief, He tainted her chaste ears; she yet unknown, His breath was treason, though his words were none. Treason to her and me, he dared me then, (Under the covert of a flattering smile,) To bring her where she is, not as she is, Alive for lust, not dead for (Chastity:
The resolution of my soul, out-dared,) I swore and taxed my faith with a sad oath; Which I maintain; here take her she was mine, When she was living, but now dead, she is thine.

sp.speaker: Kin.
Cæl.
sp.l: A constant wife.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Am I confounded twice? Blasted with wonder.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: O delude we not. Thou art too true to live again, too fair To be my Cælestine, too constant far To be a woman.

sp.speaker: Cæl.
sp.l: Not to be thy wife, But first I plead my duty, and salute The world again.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l:
My King, my Son, know all, I am an Actor in this mystery, And bear the chiefest part. The Father I, It was I that ministered to her chaste blood, A true somniferous potion, which did steal
Her thoughts to sleep, and flattered her with death: I called it a quick poisoned drug, to try The Bridegrooms love, and the Brides constancy. He in the passion of his love did fight, A combat with affection; so did both, She for the poison strove, he for his oath: Thus like a happy Father, I have won, A constant Daughter, and a loving Son.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Mirror of Maidens, wonder of thy name, I give thee that art given, pure, chaste, the same Here Wat: I would not part (for the worlds pride) So true a Bridegroom, and so chaste a Bride.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: My Liege, to wed a Comical event, To presupposed tragic Argument: Vouchsafe to exercise your eyes, and see A humorous dreadful Poet take degree.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Dreadful in his proportion or his pen?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: In both, he calls himself the whip of men.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l:
If a clear merit stand upon his praise, Reach him a Poets Crown (the honoured Bays) But if he claim it, wanting right thereto, (As many bastard Sons of Poesy do) Race down his usurpation to the ground. True Poets are with Art and Nature Crowned. But in what mould so ever this man be cast;
We make him thine Crispinus, wit and judgment, Shine in thy numbers, and thy soul I know, Will not go armed in passion against thy foe: Therefore be thou ourself; whilst ourself sit, But as spectator of this Sceane of wit.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Thanks royal Lord, for these high honours done, To me unworthy, my minds brightest fires Shall all consume themselves, in purest flame, On the Alter of your dear eternal name.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Not under us, but next us take thy Seat, "Arts nourished by Kings make Kings more great, Use thy Authority.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Demetrius. Call in that self-creating Horace, bring Him and his shadow forth.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Both shall appear, "No black-eyed star must stick in vertues Sphere.

sp.speaker: Sir Ua.
sp.l: zounds did you see him, I pray let all his Majesties most excellent dogs, be set at liberties, and have their freedoms to smell him out.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Smell whom?

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.l:
Whom? the Composer, the Prince of Poets, Horace, Horace, he is departed: in Gods name and the Kings I charge you to ring it out from all our ears, for Horaces body is departed: Master hue and cry shall --- God bless King
Williams, I cry you mercy and ask forgiveness, for mine eyes did not find in their hearts to look upon your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What news with thee Sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: News? God it is as worse news as I can desire to bring about me: our unhandsome-faced Poet does play at bo-peeps with your Grace, and cries all-hidden as boys do.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.l: Stand by, room there, back, room for the Poet.

sp.speaker: Sir Va.
sp.l: He is reprehended and taken, by Jesu I rejoice very near as much as if I had discovered a New-found Land, or the North and East Indies.

div2.stage: Enter Tucca, his boy after him with two pictures vnder his cloake, and a wreath of nettles: Horace and Bubo pul'd in by th'hornes bound both like Satyres, Sir Adam following, Mistris Miniuer with him, wearing Tuccaes chaine.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: So, tug, tug, pull the mad Bull in by the horns: So, bait one at that stake my place-mouth yelpers, and one at that stake Gurnets-head.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What busy fellow is this?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Save thee, my most gracious King of Hearts save thee, all hats and caps are thine, and therefore I vail: for but to thee great Sultan Soliman, I scorn to be thus put off or to deliver up this sconce I would.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Sir Vaughan, what is this jolly Captains name?

sp.speaker: Sir Va.
sp.l: Has a very sufficient name, and is a man has done God and his Country as good and as hot Service (in conquering this vile Monster-Poet) as ever did Saint George his horseback about the Dragon.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
I sweat for it, but Tawsoone, hold thy tongue Mondu, 
  if thou wilt 
    praise me, do it behind my back: I 
    am my weighty Sovereign one of thy grains, thy valiant vassal; ask not what I am, but read, turn over, 
    unclasp thy Chronicles: there thou shalt find buff jerkin; there read my points of war; I am one a thy Mandilian-Leaders; 
    one that enters into thy royal bands for thee; Pantilius Tucca; one of thy Kingdoms chiefest quarrellers; 
    one of thy most faithful --- fie --- fie --- fie ---

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Drunkards I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: No whirligig, one of his faithful fighters; thy drawer o royal Tamor Cham.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Go to, I pray Captain Tucca, give us all leave to do our business before the King.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: With all my heart, shi, shi, shi shake that Bear whelp when thou would.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Horace and Bubo, pray send an answer into his Majesty's ears, why you go thus in Ouids Morter-Morphesis and strange fashions of apparel.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Cur why?

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: My Lords, I was drawn into this beastly suite by head and shoulders only for love I bare to my Ningle.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Speak Ningle, thy mouth is next, belch out, belch, why ---

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
I did it to retire me from the world; And turn my Muse into a Timonist,
Loathing the general Leprosy of Sin, Which like a plague runs through the souls of men: I did it but to ---

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: But to bite every Motley-head vice by the nose, you did it Ningle to play the Bugbear Satyr, and make a Camp royal of fashion-mongers quake at your paper Bullets; you Nasty Tortoise, you and your Itchy Poetry break out like Christmas, but once a year, and then you keep a-revelling, and Arraigning, and a-scratching of men's faces, as though you were Tyber the long-tailed Prince of Rats, do you?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Horace.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.l: Silence, pray let all words be strangled, or held fast between your teeth.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l:
Under control of my dread Sovereign, We are thy Judges; thou that didst Arraign, Art now prepared for condemnation; Should I but bid thy Muse stand to the Bar, Thyself against her wouldst give evidence: For flat rebellion against the Sacred laws, Of divine Poesy: herein most she missed, Thy pride and scorn made her turn Satirist, And not her love to virtue (as thou Preachest) Or should we minister strong pills to thee: What lumps of hard and indigested stuff, Of bitter Satirism, of Arrogance,
Of Self-love, of Detraction, of a black And stinging Insolence should we fetch up? But none of these, we give thee what is more fit, With stinging nettles Crown his stinging wit.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Well said my Poetical huckster, now he is in thy handling rate him, do rate him well.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O I beseech your Majesty, rather than thus to be netted, I will have my Satyrs coat pulled over mine ears, and be turned out of the nine Muses Service.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: And I too, let me be put to my shifts with mine Ningle.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: By Jesu so you shall M. Bubo; flea off this hairy skin M. Horace, so, so, so, untruss, untruss.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: His Poetical wreath my dapper punk-fetcher.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: Nay your oohs, nor your Callin-oes cannot serve your turn; your tongue you know is full of blisters with railing, your face full of pocky-holes and pimples, with your fiery inventions: and therefore to preserve your head from aching, this Biggin is yours, --- nay by Jesu you shall be a Poet, though not Laurefied, yet Nettlefied, so:

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
Sirrah stinker, thou art but untrussed now, I owe thee a whipping still, and I will pay it: I have laid rods in Piss and Vinegar for thee: It shall not be the
Whipping of the Satyr, nor the Whipping of the blind-Bear, but of a counterfeit Juggler, that steals the name of Horace.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: How? counterfeit? does he usurp that name?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Yes indeed if it please your Grace, he does sup up that abominable name.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l:
He does O King Cambises, he does: thou hast no part of Horace in thee but his name, and his damnable vices: thou hast such a terrible mouth, that thy beard is afraid to peep out: but, look here you staring Leviathan, here is the sweet visage of Horace; look parboiled-face, look; Horace had a trim long-beard, and a reasonable good face for a Poet, (as faces go nowadays) Horace did not screw and wriggle himself into great Men's familiarity, (impudently) as thou dost: nor wear the Badge of Gentlemen's company, as thou dost thy Taffeta sleeves tacked too only with some points of profit: No, Horace had not his face punched full of Eyelet-holes, like the cover of a warming-pan: Horace loved Poets well, and gave Coxcombs to none but fools; but thou lovest none, neither Wise men nor fools, but thyself: Horace was a goodly Corpulent Gentleman, and not so lean a hollow-cheeked Scrag as thou art: No, here is thee Copy of thy countenance, by this will I learn to make a number of villainous faces more, and to look scurvily upon the world, as
thou dost.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Sir Vaughan will you minister their oath?

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: Master Asinius Bubo, you shall swear as little as you can, one oath shall dam up your Innocent mouth.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Any oath Sir, I will swear anything.

sp.speaker: Sir Ua.
sp.l: You shall swear by Phoebus (who is your Poets good Lord and Master,) that hereafter you will not hire Horace, to give you poesies for rings, or hand-kerchers, or knives which you understand not, nor to write your Love-letters; which you (in turning of a hand) set your marks upon, as your own: nor you shall not carry Latin Poets about you, till you can write and read English at most; and lastly that you shall not call Horace your Ningle.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: By Phoebus I swear all this, and as many oaths as you will, so I may trudge.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Trudge then, pay your legs for Fees, and be discharged.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Tprooth --- run Red-cap, ware horns there.

sp.speaker: Sir Va.
sp.l: Now Master Horace, you must be a more horrible swearer, for your oath must be (like your wits) of many colours; and like a Brokers book of many parcels.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Read, read; the inventory of his oath.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I will swear till my hair stands upon end, to be rid of thirsting, O this sting.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: It is not your sting of conscience, is it?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Upon him: Inprimis.

sp.speaker: Sir Uaugh.
sp.l: Jnprimis, you shall swear by Phoebus and the half a score Muses lacking one: not to swear to hang yourself, if you thought any. Man, Ooman or Silde, could write Plays and Rimes, as well-favoured ones as yourself.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Well said, hast brought him the the gallows already?

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.l: You shall swear not to bombast out a new Play, with the old linings of Jests, stolen from the Temples Revels.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: To him old Tango.

sp.speaker: Sir Ua.
sp.l: Moreover, you shall not sit in a Gallery, when your Comedies and Interludes have entered their Actions, and there make vile and bad faces at every line, to make Gentleman have an eye to you, and to make Players afraid to take your part.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Thou shalt be my Ningle for this.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l: Besides, you must forswear to venture on the stage, when your Play is ended, and to exchange courtesies, and complements with Gallants in the Lords rooms, to make all the house rise up in Arms, and to cry that is Horace, that is he, that is he, that is he, that pens and purges Humours and diseases.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: There boy, again.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l:
Secondly, when you bid all your friends to the marriage of a poor couple, that is to say: your Wits and
necessities, alias dictus, to the rifling of your Muse: alias, your Muses up-sitting: alias a Poets Whitson-Ale; you shall swear that within three days after, you shall not abroad, in Book-binders shops, brag that your Vice-roys or Tributory-Kings, have done homage to you, or paid quarterage.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I will buss thy head Holofernes.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.l: Moreover and Inprimis, when a Knight or Gentleman of worship, does give you his passport, to travail in and out to his Company, and gives you money for Gods sake; I trust in Jesu, you will swear (tooth and nail) not to make scald and wry-mouth Jests upon his Knight-hood, will you not?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I never did it by Parnassus.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Would swear by Parnassus and lie too, Doctor Doddipol?

sp.speaker: Sir Va.
sp.l: Thirdly, and last of all saving one, when your Plays are misliked at Court, you shall not cry Mew like a Pussycat, and say you are glad you write out of the Courtiers Element.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Let the Element alone, it is out of thy reach.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.l:
In briefliness, when you Sup in Taverns, amongst your betters, you shall swear not to dippe your Manners in too much sauce, nor at Table to fling Epigrams, Emblems, or Play-speeches about you (like Hailstones) to keep you out of the terrible danger of the Shot, upon pain to sit at the upper end of the
Table, at the left hand of Carlo Buffon: swear all this, by Apollo and the eight or nine Muses.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: By Apollo, Helicon, the Muses (who march three and three in a rank) and by all that belongs to Pernassus, I swear all this.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Bear witness.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: That fearful wreath, this honour is your due, All Poets shall be Poet-Apes but you; Thanks (Learnings true Mecoenas, Poesies king) Thanks for that gracious ear, which you have lent, To this most tedious, most rude argument.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Our spirits have well been feasted; he whose pen Draws both corrupt, and clear blood from all men: (Careless what vein he pricks) let him not rave, When his own fides are struck, blows, blows, do crave.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Kings-truce, my noble Herb-a-grace; my Princely sweet-William, a boon --- Stay first, Is it a match or no match, Lady Furniuall Is it?

sp.speaker: Sir Ad. & Sir quint.
sp.l: A match?

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: Aye, a match, since he hath hit the Mistress so often in the fore-game, we will even play out a rubbers.

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.l: Take her for me.

sp.speaker: Sir quin.
sp.l: Take her for thyself, not for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Uau.
sp.l: Play out your rubbers in Gods name, by Jesu I will never bowl more in your Alley, Widow.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: My Chain.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.l: My Purse.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I will Chain thee presently, and give thee ten pound and a purse: a boon my Liege: --- dance o my delicate Rufus, at my wedding with this reverend Antiquary; is it done? would thou?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will give thee Kingly honour: Night and Sleep, With silken Ribands would tie up our eyes, But Mistress Bride, one measure shall be led, In scorn of Mid-nights haste, and then to bed.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.l: Gentlemen, Gallants, and you my little Swaggerers that fight low: my tough hearts of Oak that stand to it so valiantly, and are still within a yard of your Captain: Now the Trumpets (that set men together by the ears) have left their Tantara-rag-boy, let us part friends. I recant, bear witness all you Gentlefolks (that walk in the Galleries) I recant the opinions which I held of Courtiers, Ladies, and Citizens, when once (in an assembly of Friars) I railed upon them: that Heretical Libertine Horace, taught me so to mouth it. Besides, it was when stiff Tucca was a boy: it was not Tucca that railed and roared then, but the Devil and his Angels: But now, Kings-truce, the Captain Summons a parley, and delivers himself and his prating company into your hands, upon what composition you will. Are you pleased? and I will dance Friskin for joy, but if you be not, by the Lord I will see you all --- here for your two pence a piece again, before I will lose your company. I know now some be come hither with cheeks swollen as big with hisses, as if they had the tooth-ach: uds-foot, if I stood by them, I would be so bold as --- entreat them to hiss in another place. Are you advised what you do when you hiss? you blow away Horaces revenge: but if you set your hands and Seals to this, Horace will write against it, and you may have more sport: he shall not lose his labour, he shall not turn his blank verses into waste paper: No, my Poëtasters will not laugh at him, but will untruss him again, and again, and again. I will tell you what you shall do, cast your little Tucca into a Bell: do, make a Bell of me, and be all you my clappers, upon condition, we may have a lusty peal, this cold weather: I have but two legs left me, and they are both yours: Good night my two penny Tenants God night.

div.p: Ad Detractorem. Non potes in Nugas dicere plura meas, Ipse ego quam dixi. --- Qui se mirantur, in illas Virus habe: Nos hac nouimus esse nihil
